recipientOrganization.description:
Life Cycle UK is a Bristol-based charity that has been transforming lives through cycling since 1999. Cycling can be a fantastic agent for change: it improves physical and mental health, enables those on low-incomes to access jobs, the lonely to better engage with community life and young people on their journey to independence.

Our award winning Inclusive Cycling Projects support people with disabilities, mental health illness, offenders, isolated older people and disadvantaged youngsters to improve their lives. We do this by providing affordable refurbished bikes, cycle skills training, community-led cycle rides “ and training socially excluded people as qualified bike mechanics.
recipientOrganization.name: Life Cycle UK

recipientOrganization.name: Bridge Project - North Somerset
recipientOrganization.description:
The Bridge Project is an independent organisation with charitable aims which has been set up to provide activities for people with mental health, substance misuse and mild learning impairment (including social learning) who do not currently receive adequate support from statutory agencies in North Somerset. It seeks to address unmet need with innovative approaches, which can then be funded more substantially by other bodies in the longer term, taking care to demonstrate outcomes effectively._x000D_
It seeks in particular to assist the Carlton Centre in work which does not (or as in this case) does not yet receive statutory or other forms of funding. In this way it addresses need that is currently unmet, frequently avoiding harmful consequences, while establishing a range of positive outcomes._x000D_
It has made a number of successful applications to Quartet in the past which have led to a thriving horticultural project at Rectors Way Allotments. This has led to many successful outcomes (including achieving Outstanding in Weston in Bloom) and a number of beneficiaries becoming much more successfully occupied. The latter has included qualifications and jobs and individuals being helped to be discharged from Mental Health Services because of improved confidence and wellbeing.

recipientOrganization.name: Stepping Out Theatre
recipientOrganization.description:
Stepping Out Theatre is a registered charity and the UKs leading mental health theatre company. With 58 production credits to our name, we work with over 100 mental health service users every year, using performing arts as an instrument for recovery, personal development and social change. _x000D_
Our aims are:_x000D_
1) To relieve the conditions of mental health service users through the medium of theatre. _x000D_
2) To advance the education of the public about mental health in order to raise their awareness, by producing plays which deal with this issue and counter negative stereotypes of people with mental health problems._x000D_
3) To advance the education and training of mental health service users and their allies to develop their creative talents, build supportive networks and produce high quality theatre on mental health themes. _x000D_
We deliver a range of programmes including workshops, mentoring, educational opportunities, social trips and a holistic package of support including housing, benefits, career progression and emotional welfare. We have an excellent track record involving service users in range of work from large scale community theatre productions to high quality professional performances on mental health themes giving them a voice and a platform to bring compelling stories alive on stage.

recipientOrganization.description: The Cirdan Sailing Trust was established in 1983 and has provided over 33,000 young people from the UK with self-development, integration and learning opportunities through the challenge of life at sea aboard our large sailing vessels. The focus of our service is on working almost exclusively with groups from youth organisations that work with young people whose lives are disadvantaged in some way. A sailing voyage takes the young people away from their geographical surroundings and removes them from their usual environment where they be may be subject to negative influences and other pressures that are detrimental to their development and well-being. Our sailing vessels provide them with a challenging, alien environment where they have to understand and accept authority, live and work as a team and be resilient. They are actively involved in every aspect of running and sailing the vessel. This includes deck work, planning and navigation, keeping watch, learn to cook for themselves and each other and keeping a tidy ship. As their voyage of discovery progresses, the young people learn to accept the disciplines and constraints of life on board and they face up to the challenges that produce the positive outcomes. The Trust is partly self-funding through the collection of voyage fees which, by careful management, are kept as low as possible. However, very few of the organisations and young people who wish to benefit from the experience we offer are in a position to cover the costs involved. They rely on support from our voyage of Discovery Fund scheme to supplement the limited monies raised through their own resources to ensure the experience can be made available to their young people. Most seasons, none of our groups can cover the full voyage fee so all have to supplemented through our Voyage of Discovery Fund scheme. We have always supported the majority of those who sail with at a level dependent upon their particular needs. Over the last few years, our support has risen from an average level of 40% to nearer 60%. We anticipate this trend will continue into the foreseeable future if we are to ensure our service is available to those who can most benefit. The experience we provide for young people makes a significant contribution to the development of their life skills, stimulates their desire to learn, improves their attitude towards authority and generally enhances their health and well-being. Whilst we are not in a position to provide a service for wheelchair users, as all participants do require a degree of mobility and coordination, we work closely with the youth leaders to tailor voyages to the needs of the young people in an effort to make the experience we offer inclusive. Together with the support we provide through our Voyage of Discovery Fund this allows us generally to work with young people from all areas of society irrespective of their culture, religion, attainment level, social standing or special needs. Throughout each season, we receive a great deal of feedback from the youth leaders who involve their young people in sailing residentials on board our vessels. The overriding view of these leaders in that the benefits gained from the experience are of enormous value, in particular with regard to the sense of achievement, self-confidence, and ability to face challenges. Very many of the young people who sail with us have restricted and insular view of life, often relying heavily on others to provide structure and organisation. The challenge off-shore sailing adventure with the rigidity of an on-board life allows the individual to develop naturally through the necessity of cooperation and the feeling of total inclusion as a valued member of the team. The leaders who accompany the young people are encouraged to discuss their desired outcomes with the Skipper prior to and during the voyage. This is reviewed from time to time during debriefing sessions to ensure their objectives are being met.
recipientOrganization.name: Cirdan Sailing Trust

recipientOrganization.description: CAC was established in 1939 as one of the original 200 Citizens Advice bureaux opened by the National Council of Social Services. From its inception, the service has been volunteer-led and existed to provide free, confidential, impartial advice to the citizens of Colchester to help them with the problems they face. The aims of CAC are to: • Provide free confidential and impartial advice and information for the benefit of the local community • To influence the development of social policies and services • To ensure that individuals do not suffer through lack of knowledge or inability to express their needs effectively. These aims contribute to the reduction of crime and antisocial behavior as: • We help clients escaspe from the cycle of long term debt, enabling them to return to economic activity. Last year we helped clients write off nmore that £600,000 of debt • We help clients to claim the benefits they are entitled to. Last year, we helped claim £64,000 of additional benefits • We help clients understand their rights and responsibilities at tenants. Lasr year, we helped with 3,000 housing issues • Help clients resolve employment issues. Last year, we helped with 1,200 employment issues To achieve these aims, we provide: • Face-to-face advice 5 mornings per week from our Crouch St Office (drop in service) • Follow-up appointments 5 days per week for more complex cases (casework) • Telephone advice 5 afternoons per week • Email advice 5 days per week via the Colchester Advice Network (CAN) • Face-to-face advice for 5 sessions per week at Colchester Central Library • Face-to-face advice on Wednesdays at Wivenhoe library (enabling library opening on a day when it would otherwise be closed). In addition, we run discrete projects to provide: • 1 session of face-to-face advice at the Lakes Mental Health unit, with follow-up casework where needed • 5 days specialist debt advice for Colchester Borough Homes tenants via home visits with follow up specialist casework. • 5 days advice via webchat • Weekly evening advice session at the Military Corrective Training Centre (MCTC) with follow up specialist casework. • Financial Assessment Benefits Advice (FABA). • Home Visiting Service for Essex County Council (ECC) benefits service. (Referral basis) In total, CAC provided advice to 12,000 clients last year (discrete client contacts) with 16,350 separate issues*. A bulk of advice (42%) related to debt, followed by benefits and tax credits (18%) and employment (10%). We monitor client volumes on a quarterly basis to ensure client contacts are in line with target. We also monitor trends in the mix of issues to ensure the skills of our advisers matches emerging client needs. * These figures include telephone and webchat advice. Some client contacts via these channels will be from outside the borough.
recipientOrganization.name: Colchester Advice Centre

recipientOrganization.description: Open Road is a registered charity with a strong and dynamic track record built up over 27 years. Our mission is to empower a diverse range of individuals, families and communities to lead healthy and more meaningful lives, free from addiction, offending behaviour and disadvantage, to ensure healthier, happier lifestyles. With over 100 staff and over 270 volunteers, we work across Essex from centres in Clacton, Colchester, Chelmsford, Harlow and Basildon and across Norfolk, Suffolk and Medway. We also operate outreach services at 28 different sites, working alongside families, carers, GP surgeries and hospitals. In 2016/17, over 10,500 people with drug and alcohol problems directly benefitted from the services we deliver. Open Road have been successfully working with drug users for over 27 years enabling individuals to break the cycle of addiction and get their lives, and those of their families, back on track and into recovery. Service users are able to access services through a number of ways, including self-referral, GP’s, Criminal Justice agencies, housing associations, other voluntary organisations. As an organisation we embrace the ‘no wrong door’ philosophy. Working within local communities we are acutely aware of the problems that individuals and families face linked to substance misuse. Open Road staff and volunteers work daily with problematic drug users offering treatment and providing counselling, therapy, benefits and housing advice, debt management, creative activities and employment support. Through providing help with access to training, volunteering, education and employment opportunities, Open Road works to ensure that people fully re-integrate into society and ultimately attain a meaningful way of life. Open Road have run the Colchester SOS bus for 10 years and have recently taken part in a successful pilot to deliver an SOS service in Chelmsford. As a result of the pilot we will now be delivering the service on a permanent basis from April 2017. The SOS bus projects work to support the night time economy, and help to keep the town and city centres safe on weekend nights. The SOS Bus has a primary role to provide a safe haven for any vulnerable person, irrespective of their age, race, sexual orientation or religion. The services operate between 8:30pm and 4:00am every Friday, Saturday and Bank Holidays' Sunday nights in Colchester and Chelmsford Town and City Centres. It is the first point of contact for any person who is at risk. We provide medical and emotional support to anyone who gets into difficulty. The SOS Bus team provide support to those in need. Volunteers are in place to provide welfare support, respect confidentiality, and be a calming influence. Our volunteers directly help any visitors to the bus and if needed, will contact other services to provide further assistance. Volunteers support the on-board medics assisting them where needed. The SOS project provides a safe space for individuals and supports them in getting home safely without any issues. In the case of young people visiting the bus for assistance, our volunteers contact the young person's parents to reassure them that their child is safe and arrange for the young person to be collected or be safely dropped off at home. The SOS Bus also provides free bottles of water and medical care, as well as advice and information to visitors. The service proactively reduces the need to involve Police and Paramedics, and has significantly reduced the number of local A&E visits. The service also works in partnership with local businesses, pubs and clubs to ensure that the town centre is a safer place for weekend revellers.   In addition to our core substance misuse services, we run other projects including: The Essex Appropriate Adult service, ensuring that young people and vulnerable adults are supported through the police custody process. This project relies on our dedicated volunteer Appropriate Adults, who give their time free of charge to be available to support young people and vulnerable adults people in custody, ensuring that their welfare rights are adhered to at all times, 365 days per year from 7am to 11pm. Indeed this service has been so successful because of the dedication of our Appropriate Adults volunteers, we now provide an on call service between 11pm - 7am, 365 days per year for serious crimes. We provide a mentoring project in Norfolk and Suffolk, and a women's service in Essex in partnership with the Community Rehabilitation Companies, providing volunteer mentors to those who are part of the criminal justice system. Again, this project is driven by volunteers, supported by paid Service Coordinators, who mentor probationers allowing them to reintegrate into society, to ensure that they do not fall back into offending behaviour patterns. We provide counselling, anger management and drug and alcohol awareness training to the Military Correction Training Centre (MCTC). Our qualified counselling team support detainees who have recognised that they need help dealing with drug and alcohol issues or with anger issues. Detainees accessing this very successful service often come from difficult backgrounds or have had challenging upbringings, leading to these issues in adult life. Common feedback from the detainees is that they can't believe it took them being detained to receive the support they so desperately needed around the various issues they have struggled with. The success of this service has meant that, this year, we were awarded the new contract to continue to provide the service until 2019, having provided this service for the last 10 years. We provide a Young People’s Drug and Alcohol services e in Medway both in the community and at HM YOI Cookham Wood. This service proactively helps and supports young people in the Medway area, who are experiencing various issues involving drug and alcohol abuse. The Medway team actively work with the local schools, undertaking visits and making presentations to the students, which has proved very successful in increasing student awareness of the dangers of drugs and alcohol misuse and leading to many young people accessing our services.
recipientOrganization.name: Open Road

recipientOrganization.description: Rainbow Services works to alleviate the effects of disadvantage, deprivation and social exclusion through imaginative projects that support, enable and develop people and organisations and which stimulate beneficial change in the local community and beyond. We do this through the following current initiatives: - Rainbow Services provides infrastructure support to local voluntary and community groups, holding regular meetings and publishing a weekly e-bulletin sharing information on subjects relevant to the sector, giving advice and guidance, delivering workshops on topics such as GDPR, and facilitating a voluntary sector hub with affordable room hire and office space. In 16/17 we sent 50 e-briefings out to over 200 organisations; - Rainbow Services also provides direct services to the local community via our Community Builder project, which is currently supporting local older residents. across Harlow who are socially isolated. This project uses an Asset Based Community Development approach to work with older people to develop sustainable social groups, supported by volunteers, and co-ordinate safety and health information sessions combined with social opportunities. In 16/17 over 900 older people were supported ; -Our Business Engagement project is working to facilitate a more structured approach to Corporate Social Responsibility and to create a better pipeline for business involvement and volunteering opportunities with the wider Voluntary Sector and local community, in partnership with Harlow Chamber of Commerce. Started in August 2017, the project has already engaged with 17 VCSE and 5 business organisations and is in the process of matching 6 volunteer opportunities; - Our Workshop project is a contracted arrangement (with Sodexo) to provide a workplace environment for offenders who have received a community service order through the courts in an environment that is, whilst punitive, also rehabilitative and constructive. This project is the only community and voluntary sector run programme which Sodexo offers in Essex and is creating real opportunities for offenders to give back to their community by building and refurbishing items for local groups and organisations, whilst developing transferable skills which could lead to more positive activities on completion of their order. In 16/17 we enabled the completion of 10,515 unpaid work hours and feedback includes "I have learnt skills I didn't think were possible"; - we also promote volunteering both internally and externally, and provide diverse volunteering opportunities within Rainbow Services, including intergenerational, reception, workshop, health programmes, and within communications. These opportunities have been used as springboards to paid employment for many of our volunteers, and for others who require supportive environments we have been able to facilitate learning and development through volunteering. In 16/17 2,984 volunteer hours were completed via Rainbow Services; - we pilot and test new ideas with partners. In previous years this has included a Health Navigation Project, which led to the subsequent development of Care Navigation in West Essex. Currently we are working with groups of VCSE organisations, local and district authority representatives, education providers, and community members to find solutions to youth mental health and youth inactivity in Harlow. In addition to this, in November and December 2017 we worked with Passmores Academy in a test programme they were running to tackle disengagement in education. They released 8 young people in Year 8 who were regularly being sent to the STEP (Students Towards Excellent Progress) team office into community activities, supported by the Alternative Provision Officer (Jo Busson). They tried several different activities, including intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow Services. It was found that the most successful elements of the programme were the intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow, where 2 young boys have continued to volunteer and 1 is considering it, and visits from ex-offenders to discuss their experiences. The young people were also better behaved and focused when doing practical activities which kept them busy. This has led to the development of this Workshop programme, which Passmores is supporting and which has been presented to the Safer Harlow Partnership, members of which have also approved the project and offered support.
recipientOrganization.name: Rainbow Services

recipientOrganization.description: Open Door works with young people and vulnerable adults to help them realise their aspirations and address any barriers that may stop them from achieving their full potential. This is achieved by providing a range of free help and support services that help people live healthy, safe and happy lives. Making fully accessible the information and support that enables people to make informed decisions. Helping tackle injustice and inequality by addressing issues that may prevent people from gaining access to opportunities. Providing a range of help and support services including: YPLA- Advocacy and support for children and young people who are in care. Missing Children- Independent return home interviews for children and young people who have gone missing. TIME- A project aimed at reducing repeat missing episodes by helping address the causal factors, providing advocacy and coaching to encourage safer responses to situations which previously led to missing episodes. SIP- Social Isolation project for care leavers. Mentoring & Coaching for children and young people. Interventions- Therapeutic interventions including counselling, anger management, play therapy etc. for children and young people. HASS- Housing Advice and Support . SOS- Schools outreach providing workshops around bullying, resilience and self esteem. FIF South- Counselling & Mediation in South Essex FIF West- Coaching and mentoring in West Essex. Open Door operates from two sites in Thurrock with a satellite office in Basildon.

grants.description: The project will provide a platform for females from the Black and ethnic minority communities to come together in a spirit of community and learning to access basic IT skills. Our aim is to have a sustainable project and as such in year two we aim to additionally offer an intermediate IT course.     Given that many of our service users have never used a desk top, a lap top or a tablet, it is necessary to first make individuals familiar with the hardware and allow them to feel comfortable around the equipment. It is vital to create a comfortable environment where individuals are not only attending to learn but attending to make friends and contacts who will become their external support networks. Support networks can prove vital in helping to support and encourage the educational progression of individuals and can lead to enhanced computer literacy skills, as often individuals will take their learning home, share their learning and therefore independently expand their learning.     By virtue of the project individuals will learn the skills to set up social network accounts and thereby stay in touch with family and friends via Skype, Facebook, and Twitter etc. Through our other projects we have learnt that some of our female service users who, for example, have had to leave their loved ones behind and seek refuge or asylum in this country often are devoid of any support, financial or otherwise. Therefore they may not have access to resources which enables them to stay in touch with their loved ones. This adds to their sense of isolation and exclusion in a country in which they know and have very little. This can and does affect their mental and physical health. Therefore, the ability to connect with loved ones not only breaks their sense of isolation/exclusion but can help improve their physical and mental wellbeing which is essential to their effective integration in societal life and in them exercising active citizenship.     Participants will learn to surf the net, to access educational websites; health websites; to type in and learn of what is happening locally so they can attend events and meet people. Additionally individuals will be encouraged and supported in making online applications for i.e. benefits; colleges; employment opportunities. They will be introduced to Microsoft word and will be taught how to write a document, save a document and print a document etc.     Emails are an instant and effective way of communication and participants will be assisted in creating email accounts, managing emails and will be encouraged to regularly email other participants of the project in order to build their confidence in communicating in this way.   Through the project our aim is not only to provide and develop digital skills and experiences but it’s also to encourage excluded individuals and communities to access and benefit from educational, employment and training opportunities that will help break their sense of isolation and exclusion.

recipientOrganization.description:
WDGB's main aims are to alleviate hardship and to reduce homelessness._x000D_
We run friendly, open 'drop-in' surgeries to give advice and help to homeless people or those who are threatened with homelessness. We establish the cause of the homelessness (e.g.  relationship breakdown, eviction etc) and identify any other relevant issues (e.g. disabilities, mental health issues, addictions, domestic violence etc) We provide homeless people with an understandable explanation of their rights regarding re-housing._x000D_
Our core service is helping homeless people find rented accommodation and providing deposit guarantees to help them get into a private tenancy, where they are not eligible for statutory homeless support. We give practical hands-on support with form-filling, phone calls and other obstacles to securing a tenancy. We are now offering longer-term follow up support visits and are developing the befriending aspects of our work. This enables us to meet the longer term needs of service users.
recipientOrganization.name: KeySteps (formerly WDGB)

recipientOrganization.description: Our Aims • To provide one-on-one tailored support specifically designed to help individual care receivers develop skills for living independently, increase involvement in the community, break their social isolation by encouraging them to engage in social activities and learn other important life skills. • To provide a listening ear to service users and carers after which we are able signpost to information about services and support, which could be of benefit thereby providing emotional and practical support. • To alleviate demands placed on carers by providing respite on a regular basis allowing them time to pursue their own interests and activities or simply having time to relax. • To engage with carers and care receivers identifying ways in which we can support them to cope with their diverse needs. • Provide support to service users who do not have a carer. • To provide support for geographically isolated service users with a mental health diagnosis. The Essex Respite and Care Association (ERCA) works with mental health service users, with critical or substantial need, and their carers in Essex. Our aim is to provide one-on-one tailored support specifically designed to help individual care receivers develop skills for living independently, increase involvement in the community, break their social isolation by encouraging them to engage in social activities and learn other important life skills. To provide a listening ear to service users and carers after which we are able signpost to information about services and support, which could be of benefit thereby providing emotional and practical support. Or project alleviates demands placed on carers by providing respite on a regular basis allowing them time to pursue their own interests and activities or simply having time to relax. We engage with carers and care receivers identifying ways in which we can support them to cope with their diverse needs. We also provide support to service users who do not have a carer and support for geographically isolated service users with a mental health diagnosis. ERCA aims to enhance the quality of life of its clients by encouraging them to leave their home environment, our support workers first objective is to establish a ‘trust’ with the client to make them feel at ease whilst discussing which activity programme or needs that would benefit their condition. The support worker can provide a ‘voice’ for the client and due to the close one-to-one support provided are able to speak on their behalf if necessary with the client’s approval. The service user will discuss with our support worker which activities they wish to undertake. ERCA provide support and transport so that clients are able to keep health and other appointments, which they may normally not be able to attend due to isolation or anxiety. They support them to go into the community for something as simple as buying food, clothes and pay bills thereby benefitting and empowering the service user to learn the necessary life skills to live independently. Our Activity Programme helps clients in maintaining their physical as well as mental health. ERCA have found that clients become more responsible for their own health and treatment when they are encouraged to attend these appointments regularly which leads to better and improved health. Weekly interaction between the support worker and client enables the support worker to monitor the client’s illness and then feedback any change to the carer so that assistance can be organised quickly without the need for admission to hospital. The Activities Project also enables carers to have respite, knowing the family member is being cared for by ERCA, which can be particularly important for full-time carers, helping to ease any tensions in their relationships.
recipientOrganization.name: Essex Respite & Care Association

recipientOrganization.description: Kids Inspire supports children and young people age 0-25 who are at an educational, social and/or economic disadvantage. Many of the children have experienced trauma, bereavement, family breakdown, bullying, or have emerging mental health issues. These experiences/ disorders lead to emotional and behavioural difficulties, such as self-harm, substance abuse, risk-taking, truancy, anxiety, depression, aggression or withdrawal. As a result, young people struggle to engage with their education, families and communities; which in turn prevents them reaching their full potential. Without support, issues continue to disrupt children’s education and risk escalating and continuing into adulthood. Kids Inspire create bespoke packages of support tailored to individual needs. Where it will benefit the child, we also support their parents and siblings. Services include the following: * Individual Therapy: including clinically proven counselling, Arts Psychotherapy, complementary therapies and talking therapy. *Group Work: including Lunch Club, Youth Forum, Dramatherapy and Filmmaking. *Mentoring: support and guidance on a one-to-one basis, provided by trained volunteers. *Coaching: supporting disadvantaged young people to improve their emotional health and mental wellbeing. Referrals come from local GPs, Primary/ Secondary/ Special Schools, EWMHS, Social Services, paediatricians, Health Visitors, Family Solutions teams, third sector agencies, and self-referrals. Kids Inspire empowers children and young people to make sense of their experiences and feelings to improve their emotional wellbeing. We achieve this by supporting service users to develop the knowledge and tools required to build resilience and coping mechanisms; enabling them to manage independently long-term. We address root causes rather than simply treating symptoms, to achieve outcomes that last. Kids Inspire believe that supporting children to cope with emotional and behavioural difficulties is essential for them to reach their full potential.
recipientOrganization.name: Kids Inspire

recipientOrganization.description: The stated objectives of Thurrock Mind are: - • To promote mental health and to assist in relieving and rehabilitating persons suffering from mental disorder or conditions of emotional or mental distress requiring advice or treatment. • To promote debate on mental health issues and disseminate information concerning the same and to educate the public in matters relating to mental health. Thurrock Mind exists to promote mental health, to foster and encourage greater understanding of mental health problems; to aid the development of good quality voluntary and statutory mental health services and to represent the concerns and common interests of users of the service, their families and members of the public. Those people who are labelled, treated or diagnosed as mentally ill have the same rights as any other person and should not be disadvantaged or subject to prejudice. Mind recognises the value of people with experience of mental distress and wishes to listen and learn from them. It seeks to foster and enable user consultation and participation in the planning and delivery of mental health service. We provide services for Thurrock adults experiencing emotional and mental distress and our main activities are; Advocacy • Care Act Advocacy - Thurrock Mind in partnership with Thurrock Centre for Independent Living (TCIL) provides a Thurrock-based advocacy service, with local knowledge. We combine advocacy with active support such as help with filling in forms, making phone calls and signposting. The service is for adults from the following client groups: Learning Disability, Mental Health, Sensory Impairment, Acquired Brain Injury, Substantial Difficulty, Dementia, Drug / Alcohol) and their carers. • Independent Mental Health Advocate (IMHA)- This is a service for Thurrock adults who are eligible under Mental Health Act 1983 (Amended 2007) requiring independent specialist mental health advocacy. Cariads – In partnership with TCIL and Thurrock Lifestyle Solutions, we provide information, advice and support to unpaid carers in Thurrock. Day Opportunities • Peoples space – Environment for adults, experiencing mental health problems to meet socially with peers • Personal Assistant service is available to adults, experiencing mental health problems, who are able to purchase support from their Personal Budget or self-fund (£13.50 per hour). A bespoke programme is developed for the individual, with emphasis on developing life skills, social inclusion, building confidence, increasing self-esteem and maintaining wellbeing. Peer Mentoring and Peer Support- The Peer to Peer Support Project is focused on empowerment of individuals through community. It aims to support people who have, or are likely to develop, a mental health problem to stay well. There is Peer Mentoring, which is one to one support between a peer supporter (someone who has lived mental health experience) and a peer (someone who needs support). In this partnership, the emphasis is on identifying and working towards a short term goal to improve wellbeing. The empathy that comes from being a peer supporter allows an environment of trust, so the commitment to staying well is sustained long after the partnership ends. There are also Peer Support Groups, where people come together to do something they enjoy. This could be through joining an interest group, sharing skills with others or getting out into the community. Stepping Stones- Our gardening project provides an opportunity for adults experiencing mental health problems to be involved with a varied range of horticultural activities and engage with the great outdoors. Trainees can work towards vocational goals and/or gain valuable skills in a safe and supportive environment. Therapies • Inclusion Thurrock – In partnership with SSSFT we provide;  Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT); One to one or group therapy or Computerised Cognitive Behavioural therapy (CCBT)  Recovery College- Aims to teach people to manage their mental health by learning from the tutors; one professional and the other an individual with lived experience of mental health problems. • Counselling & Groupwork for individuals or couples, and groupwork courses Anger Management, Confidence, Assertiveness, Depression, Anxiety. • Multi Ethnic Counselling Service for people from the Black and Minority Ethnic community. Volunteering – We have a range of opportunities; Trustee, retail, admin, horticulture, photography etc. World of Work In partnership with TCIL we provide the World of Work programme for people with mental health problems. We provide personalised and tailored support to enable people to become more independent and reach their potential. Individual appointments and a 12 session ‘preparing 4 work’ programme are provided. Thurrock Mind’s quality marks / standards; • ISO 9001 – We met the requirement of ISO 9001 in ‘The management of support for people experiencing emotional and mental distress.’ • Mind Quality Management • Advice Quality Standard (Advocacy & Cariads) • Investors in People-Silver • Investing in Volunteers • Mentoring & Befriending Foundation Approved Provider • British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP) • Thurrock Mind has signed the Charter for Employers who are positive about mental health; Mindful Employer Thurrock’s Shared Care Protocol involves four organisations, of which Thurrock Mind is one of them. Patients from the Community Mental Health Team will be discharged to our Recovery Transfer Facilitator, who in turn will support individuals to access community groups/activities/ services.
recipientOrganization.name: Thurrock Mind

recipientOrganization.description: Brentwood Community Print: Established in 2011, Brentwood Community Print ( BCP) is a Community Interest Company with a wealth of local experience of working with and for people with mental health illnesses. The organisation exists to support people in recovery from mental ill health to gain confidence, skills and work experience in a safe and caring environment. Everyone at Brentwood Community Print including the Directors and staff has lived experience of mental ill health and support their peers in their own recovery journeys. In addition BCP have built up a good reputation through their outreach activities that include promotional campaigns involving the fictitious character "TED" who gained acclaim through our Lottery funded courses in 2015/16 with our confidence and empowerment courses to members of the public and "Good mental health in the workplace" presentations to local employers, including the Jobcentre and Brentwood Council middle management.They were honoured to be included in a case study and report produced for ACAS in late 2016 and are working with the University of Essex on the recommendations from this report in designing and presenting a workshop with circa 40 employers in 2017 with further work in the pipeline. This work will place BCP in a favourable position to reduce the stigma and discrimination that surrounds the subject of Mental illness and give us opportunities to inform a wider audience about the support available within their communities. Brentwood Community Tree In 2013, BCP set up The Brentwood Mental Health Providers Forum with the aim of working together with other mental health support agencies supporting people in Brentwood to provide and promote better mental health for residents. In 2015 the Forum became the Brentwood Community Tree Partnership. Led and managed by The Director of BCP, the partnership has worked together to create promotional materials and attend events and opportunities to promote the work of the organisations in the partnership.The Community Tree currently has 18 partner organisations and more waiting to join. Activities have included the design and production of 5000 "Who can I turn to" information leaflets, funded by Brentwood Council's Community Fund ( designed and produced by people in recovery from mental health illnesses at BCP), a presentation to GPs at a Time to Learn event, and to a patient engagement team. Plus a monthly information stand at Brentwood Library. The Community Tree has worked together to successfully identify a gap in peer support provision and in January 2016, opened a social inclusion ‘Colour Me IN Café’ based at the local theatre, for people with mental ill-health, other disabilities and the general public to attend and colour, whilst forming friendships with peers and volunteers from the Community Tree partner organisations. The Colouring books have been designed and produced by people in recovery from mental health illnesses who attend Brentwood Community Print . The books have a dual purpose also providing information and contact details of the organisations on the Community Tree. Attendance has been incredibly successful with some of the most vulnerable people in our community attending on a weekly basis giving the Community Tree exposure to those in most need of the services. Due to the success a further session will open early February helping the Community Tree to reach more vulnerable adults.

recipientOrganization.description: Rainbow Services works to alleviate the effects of disadvantage, deprivation and social exclusion through imaginative projects that support, enable and develop people and organisations and which stimulate beneficial change in the local community and beyond. We do this through the following current initiatives: - Rainbow Services provides infrastructure support to local voluntary and community groups, holding regular meetings and publishing a weekly e-bulletin sharing information on subjects relevant to the sector, giving advice and guidance, delivering workshops on topics such as GDPR, and facilitating a voluntary sector hub with affordable room hire and office space. In 16/17 we sent 50 e-briefings out to over 200 organisations; - Rainbow Services also provides direct services to the local community via our Community Builder project, which is currently supporting local older residents. across Harlow who are socially isolated. This project uses an Asset Based Community Development approach to work with older people to develop sustainable social groups, supported by volunteers, and co-ordinate safety and health information sessions combined with social opportunities. In 16/17 over 900 older people were supported ; -Our Business Engagement project is working to facilitate a more structured approach to Corporate Social Responsibility and to create a better pipeline for business involvement and volunteering opportunities with the wider Voluntary Sector and local community, in partnership with Harlow Chamber of Commerce. Started in August 2017, the project has already engaged with 17 VCSE and 5 business organisations and is in the process of matching 6 volunteer opportunities; - Our Workshop project is a contracted arrangement (with Sodexo) to provide a workplace environment for offenders who have received a community service order through the courts in an environment that is, whilst punitive, also rehabilitative and constructive. This project is the only community and voluntary sector run programme which Sodexo offers in Essex and is creating real opportunities for offenders to give back to their community by building and refurbishing items for local groups and organisations, whilst developing transferable skills which could lead to more positive activities on completion of their order. In 16/17 we enabled the completion of 10,515 unpaid work hours and feedback includes "I have learnt skills I didn't think were possible"; - we also promote volunteering both internally and externally, and provide diverse volunteering opportunities within Rainbow Services, including intergenerational, reception, workshop, health programmes, and within communications. These opportunities have been used as springboards to paid employment for many of our volunteers, and for others who require supportive environments we have been able to facilitate learning and development through volunteering. In 16/17 2,984 volunteer hours were completed via Rainbow Services; - we pilot and test new ideas with partners. In previous years this has included a Health Navigation Project, which led to the subsequent development of Care Navigation in West Essex. Currently we are working with groups of VCSE organisations, local and district authority representatives, education providers, and community members to find solutions to youth mental health and youth inactivity in Harlow. In addition to this, in November and December 2017 we worked with Passmores Academy in a test programme they were running to tackle disengagement in education. They released 8 young people in Year 8 who were regularly being sent to the STEP (Students Towards Excellent Progress) team office into community activities, supported by the Alternative Provision Officer (Jo Busson). They tried several different activities, including intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow Services. It was found that the most successful elements of the programme were the intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow, where 2 young boys have continued to volunteer and 1 is considering it, and visits from ex-offenders to discuss their experiences. The young people were also better behaved and focused when doing practical activities which kept them busy. This has led to the development of this Workshop programme, which Passmores is supporting and which has been presented to the Safer Harlow Partnership, members of which have also approved the project and offered support.
recipientOrganization.name: Rainbow Services

recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Essex (HSE) is a leading family support charity based in Essex working to achieve healthy and positive outcomes for children and families. Our work comprises a long-established volunteer home visiting service, offering emotional and practical help to families experiencing difficulties, alongside a range of family groups, well-being programmes, courses and events. What makes our charity special, is that all our trained volunteers have lived experience as parents/carers themselves. We believe in the power of community mobilisation, and so invest in local areas to support local families. Our Vision is: ‘For every child and young person in Essex to grow up in a family that is strong, resilient and able to access the support they need; when and where they need it’ HSE recognises that bringing up children can be hard work. All parents and carers will, from time to time, encounter problems which make the task harder. The key to success is for parents and carers to be strong and resilient, so they can meet challenges head on, and navigate their way through or around them successfully. Through mobilising hundreds of volunteers, we support families to help themselves, developing parenting skills and improving connections in their community. Our volunteers support families struggling with: • Mental Health issues (including peri/post-natal depression, etc.) • Financial hardship • Physical health issues • Single parenthood • Low self-esteem and confidence • Domestic abuse • Isolation • Routines and boundaries • Bereavement and other significant life events The main activities of HSE are as follows: • Home-Visiting service, led by volunteers • Family Groups • School Readiness programme (e.g. Big Hopes-Big Futures) • Peri/post-natal support groups • Targeted mental health and wellbeing programmes • Counselling • Volunteer training and recruitment • Information, Advice, Guidance (IAG) and signposting • Food Bank Voucher distribution • Family activity days Our main funders are The Big Lottery Fund, BBC Children in Need, Virgin/Banardo’s PB-19yrs Contract, Essex Community Foundation, Clinical Commissioning Groups and local trusts. A new 5-Year Strategic Plan will be launched in March 2018 which will see HSE developing its funding streams to be more diverse; allowing the organisation to grow and build on excellent practice. Since April 2017, HSE has supported 368 families and 755 children, with over 200 trained volunteers offering 1,834 home visits, totalling 3,006 hours’ time across Essex. 95% of all frontline delivery continues to be entirely volunteer led. It is currently estimated that over the course of one year, the value of HSE volunteer time will be over £72,000 (ONS figures https://goo.gl/Uwz2cz). HSE measures impact across 14 individual areas of need (e.g. isolation, mental health, family conflict, etc.) with over 80% of families showing significant positive change. “My volunteer made a huge difference. Someone who’s not going to judge and always took the time to stop and listen”. We know that our model allows us to engage with those who would otherwise be considered ‘hard to reach’. Families frequently tell us the impact of a volunteer, giving their time freely, can be far more meaningful than a paid statutory professional. Isolation and mental health issues remain the top two concerns for most of the families we support, and this often means their ability to access mainstream services is limited. This provides HSE a unique opportunity to implement our proposed PICoD Project (Preventative IAG Co-Design) project; a three-year co-produced, family-led process that will develop a new model of information, advice and guidance (IAG). This will be aimed at those predominantly in the peri/post-natal period; a key period for those at risk of poor mental health and well-being. As an existing provider of peri/postnatal services in Harlow, and with a strong history of peer/ volunteer led practice, HSE are ideally positioned to lead on the project; building on our expertise and ability to engage families; ensuring that their voice is not only heard, but responded to in practical, real terms. HSE are confident that the project is deliverable as commitment has been tested with partners (e.g. Virgin/Banardo’s and University of Essex (UofE)) who say objectives are both realistic and achievable. By drawing on our existing network of partners, and engagement with families, HSE are keen to shape the future of family led practice. We believe this is achievable by harnessing the voices and opinions of service users as a tool; to shape and influence the way in which future information, advice and service delivery is commissioned. At HSE, our approach to project design, development and delivery is thorough and systematic. At concept stage, HSE appoints a Project Lead and a Project Delivery Team to draft delivery plans (in a standard format) and undertake initial research. This involves liaising with stakeholders (staff, service users, potential funders and partners, etc.); testing project feasibility; identifying resource needs; establishing project milestones/dependencies/budgets; and undertaking SWOT analysis. This forms the foundation for funding applications/development, as part of the new 2018 Funding Strategy. Upon funding success, our Development Team hands over to the Project Delivery Team, who refine proposals and manage the initiative on an ongoing basis, reporting back to Management, Trustees and Funders in a structured way. This gives assurance to stakeholders involved, that the way HSE delivers projects, is transparent and well managed.
recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Essex

Our Vision is: ‘For every child and young person in Essex to grow up in a family that is strong, resilient and able to access the support they need; when and where they need it’ HSE recognises that bringing up children can be hard work. All parents and carers will, from time to time, encounter problems which make the task harder. The key to success is for parents and carers to be strong and resilient, so they can meet challenges head on, and navigate their way through or around them successfully. Through mobilising hundreds of volunteers, we support families to help themselves, developing parenting skills and improving connections in their community. Our volunteers support families struggling with: • Mental Health issues (including peri/post-natal depression, etc.) • Financial hardship • Physical health issues • Single parenthood • Low self-esteem and confidence • Domestic abuse • Isolation • Routines and boundaries • Bereavement and other significant life events The main activities of HSE are as follows: • Home-Visiting service, led by volunteers • Family Groups • School Readiness programme (e.g. Big Hopes-Big Futures) • Peri/post-natal support groups • Targeted mental health and wellbeing programmes • Counselling • Volunteer training and recruitment • Information, Advice, Guidance (IAG) and signposting • Food Bank Voucher distribution • Family activity days Our main funders are The Big Lottery Fund, BBC Children in Need, Virgin/Banardo’s PB-19yrs Contract, Essex Community Foundation, Clinical Commissioning Groups and local trusts. A new 5-Year Strategic Plan will be launched in March 2018 which will see HSE developing its funding streams to be more diverse; allowing the organisation to grow and build on excellent practice. Since April 2017, HSE has supported 368 families and 755 children, with over 200 trained volunteers offering 1,834 home visits, totalling 3,006 hours’ time across Essex. 95% of all frontline delivery continues to be entirely volunteer led. It is currently estimated that over the course of one year, the value of HSE volunteer time will be over £72,000 (ONS figures https://goo.gl/Uwz2cz). HSE measures impact across 14 individual areas of need (e.g. isolation, mental health, family conflict, etc.) with over 80% of families showing significant positive change. “My volunteer made a huge difference. Someone who’s not going to judge and always took the time to stop and listen”. We know that our model allows us to engage with those who would otherwise be considered ‘hard to reach’. Families frequently tell us the impact of a volunteer, giving their time freely, can be far more meaningful than a paid statutory professional. Isolation and mental health issues remain the top two concerns for most of the families we support, and this often means their ability to access mainstream services is limited. This provides HSE a unique opportunity to implement our proposed PICoD Project (Preventative IAG Co-Design) project; a three-year co-produced, family-led process that will develop a new model of information, advice and guidance (IAG). This will be aimed at those predominantly in the peri/post-natal period; a key period for those at risk of poor mental health and well-being. As an existing provider of peri/postnatal services in Harlow, and with a strong history of peer/ volunteer led practice, HSE are ideally positioned to lead on the project; building on our expertise and ability to engage families; ensuring that their voice is not only heard, but responded to in practical, real terms. HSE are confident that the project is deliverable as commitment has been tested with partners (e.g. Virgin/Banardo’s and University of Essex (UofE)) who say objectives are both realistic and achievable. By drawing on our existing network of partners, and engagement with families, HSE are keen to shape the future of family led practice. We believe this is achievable by harnessing the voices and opinions of service users as a tool; to shape and influence the way in which future information, advice and service delivery is commissioned. At HSE, our approach to project design, development and delivery is thorough and systematic. At concept stage, HSE appoints a Project Lead and a Project Delivery Team to draft delivery plans (in a standard format) and undertake initial research. This involves liaising with stakeholders (staff, service users, potential funders and partners, etc.); testing project feasibility; identifying resource needs; establishing project milestones/dependencies/budgets; and undertaking SWOT analysis. This forms the foundation for funding applications/development, as part of the new 2018 Funding Strategy. Upon funding success, our Development Team hands over to the Project Delivery Team, who refine proposals and manage the initiative on an ongoing basis, reporting back to Management, Trustees and Funders in a structured way. This gives assurance to stakeholders involved, that the way HSE delivers projects, is transparent and well managed.

recipientOrganization.name: Lads Need Dads CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Who we are: Lads Need Dads CIC is a Not-For-Profit Community Interest Company, based in Tendring, North East Essex, set up to prevent potential problems and address existing ones where boys are missing a father figure in their lives. Our Mission: To empower and enable boys aged 11-15 with absent fathers or limited access to a male role model, to be motivated, responsible, capable, resilient and emotionally competent to prevent them from coming at risk of under achieving, offending, exclusion or dropping out of school. What we do: • Help boys through male-led group mentoring, to cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. • Provide boys with opportunities for adventure, to be tested and challenged, both physically and mentally. • Provide boys with practical life-skill training, community volunteering and peer mentoring opportunities. • Raise awareness and understanding of the important role fathers play in the emotional, mental and educational development and well-being of boys. Why we do it: In 2013 the Centre for Social Justice published Fractured Families: Why stability matters, which highlighted an alarming trend of fatherlessness across the UK. It found that a teenager sitting their GCSEs is more likely to own a smartphone than live with their father, (only 57 per cent of 15-year olds are still living with their fathers while 62 per cent own a smartphone), (1). Nationally almost one quarter of families with dependent children are lone-parent families. (2) This figure rises significantly in our poorest neighbourhoods, and can be as high as 75 percent. (3) Blanden (2006) (4), found a father’s low interest in his son’s education, for instance, reduces his boy’s chances of escaping poverty by 25% and at the more extreme end, 76% of all male prisoners in England and Wales had an absent father. Statistically males are the more vulnerable gender when it comes to alcohol and drug misuse, victims of murder, victims of suicide, homelessness. Lads Need Dads was set up to provide a preventative and early-intervention response to an ever-increasing social issue. Our services: ‘EQUIP’, is a six-month self-development group-work programme held in school including bush-craft and outdoor activities supported by a facilitator and a team of male mentors. Equips’ aim is to help boys cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. Engage, a practical life-skill and community volunteering programme follows Equip and takes place in the community for six-months and involves boys attending practical life-skill workshops and together with thier mentors, doing voluntary work for lone parents, pensioners and people with a disability within their local community. Jobs include, DIY, painting and decorating, gardening, shed building, etc. Inspire, a peer mentoring programme incorporating inspirational speakers and visits to inspiring places, completes the 18-month programme. We have run the 18-month pilot once through between March 2016 and August 2017 with excellent outcomes. We started another Equip Programme in May this year. This ended this month (Nov) and the boys off this programme are now attending Engage, the second part of the programme. Alongside the programme we provide on-going support for mums and carers via workshops, coffee mornings and a face-book support group. We raise awareness within the community by giving talks and presentations to community groups, attending public events etc. We run an open-ended check-in group for graduates of the programme one evening a month to keep the arm of support in place, should they need it. We run a fishing club in the summer which is open to any boy on the programme, graduate or new boy who fits our criteria. We are just about to start a guitar club for boys who want to learn to play the guitar but who can't afford lessons. All our services are provided free of charge. We have a growing team of 14 male volunteer male mentors, between the ages of 29 and 70, from a wide range of backgrounds and from the local community. Our Director board is made up of four professionals from education, social care, statutory services and the voluntary sector. We are just entering into our next round of recruitment so anticipate our volunteer numbers increasing. References: (1) Ibid, Ofcom, Children and Parents: Media User and Attitudes Report, 2013 (2) Office of National Statistics, General Lifestyle Survey Overview: A Report on the General Lifestyle Survey 2011, Chapter 3 – Households, families and people, 7 March 2013 [accessed via: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/dcp171776_302210.pdf (2/7/14)] (3) Centre for Social Justice, Fractured Families: Why stability matters, London: Centre for Social Justice, 2013, p32. (4) Blanden, J. (2006). ‘Bucking the trend’: What enables those who are disadvantaged in childhood to succeed later in life? Working Paper No 31 Corporate Document Services. London: Department for Work and Pensions. (5) Prison Reform Trust 2015.

grants.description:
Mental Health and Justice brings together a unique collaboration addressing the central dilemma in mental health, ethics and law: the tension between protecting and respecting a person’s decision-making. As law in this area commits to human rights and as the international dimension presses, sharp new challenges are arising and now is the time to take up the interdisciplinary challenge. We focus on two fundamental concepts - support in decision-making and decision-making ability – and investigate with six interlinking work-streams addressing key issues. The collaboration involves leading clinical experts, lawyers, philosophers , neuroscientists and social scientists engaging in a research network with a carefully crafted team composition and management. Highly integrated into the proposal are policy, service user-research and public engagement expertise.  We will deliver practical guidelines, policy engagement, advancement of interdisciplinary working and innovation in service-user involvement in research and public engagement.
Mental Health and Justice will build an outstanding research network in the field of mental health, ethics and law for the next decade and will provide new solutions to a vexed dilemma facing society, healthcare and law.
Keywords: mental health, supported decision-making, decision-making ability, Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, decision-making capacity, metacognition, insight.

grants.title: Mental Health and Justice

grants.description: As a controversial branch of medicine, psychiatry has become a significant ‘field of contention’, giving rise to anti-psychiatry, critical psychiatry and a psychiatric survivor movement. This research will investigate how mental health service users/survivors and dissident professionals have ‘crafted’ forms of contention, in relation to significant changes within the UK psychiatric field, over the last 30 years. Keys goals: to explore linguistic and visual expressions of psychiatric contention (such as stories, testimonies, cartoons and poems) to identify how different ‘forms’ and ‘styles’ of contestation relate to different experiences of mental ill-health (such as self-harm, paranoia and hearing voices) and/or different modes of psychiatric treatment and care (such as medication, community treatment orders and ‘recovery’). The research will be based on a significant UK resource: Asylum: the magazine for democratic psychiatry (1986-2016), the back catalogue of which has been uniquely acquired by the Wellcome Library (2015). It will be the first research project to exploit the significant research potential of the catalogue. The research will enrich our understanding of how the contestation of psychiatric knowledge has been crafted over time, and how forms of contestation have shaped, and been shaped by, the wider landscape of medicine, psychiatry and culture.

grants.description:
Feeling sexual inside and out: bodies and boundaries in forensic mental health

It is widely acknowledged that positive experiences of sexuality and intimacy play a key role in recovery from mental health challenges, and can also be areas of complexity and anxiety for service-users. In forensic mental health settings the lived experiences of service-users’ sexuality and relationships have remained overshadowed by legal and medical concerns surrounding risk and reoffending, and yet, there is a distinct lack of policy in this area.

 

The proposed project involves conducting qualitative empirical pilot research to investigate how service-users, in secure and community forensic mental health settings, experience and make meaning around their sexuality, sensuality and intimate relationships. It aims to identify the role of sexuality in recovery, and examine barriers that might exist with respect to sexual and emotional expression within these settings. Data will be collected from approximately 30 service-users, via semi-structured one-to-one interviews. Interviews will involve using visual and creative methods, such as drawing and modelling, which help participants' embodied, relational experiences. Visual and verbal data will be analysed by drawing on phenomenological and process theory, which helps make sense of the person-in-context, with special emphasis on embodiment, affectivity and intersubjectivity.

grants.description: YoHa arts organisation under the guidance of Dr Luke Mitcheson and produced by Anila Ladwa, will lead an artistic enquiry into the formation of governance through electronic record keeping in the domain of mental health care. A key aim of the project is to explore the contemporary role of databases currently utilised in the delivery of health services by the Clinical Academic Groups Addictions and the South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust. Using the non-institutional and catalyt ic methods that art offers in a care environment the project will seek to understand how databases construct a form of governance for service users and equally those that deliver those services. The principal objective of this research is to create a critical, non partisan, creative space in which all those involved are able to revisit the meanings incorporated in using databases within this health care service environment. YoHa will use the outcomes of this research and formed relationships  to develop a series of new artworks and a corresponding public engagement programme.

grants.description: Brain, Mind and Culture will be an interactive exploration of contemporary neuroscience and wider attempts at understanding the mind. It will take a non-narrative approach presenting different models and approaches, while inviting visitors to participate in real experiments. Displays will combine objects, interactive elements and creative artworks, and the gallery will integrate permanent features with spaces for active researchers to come and engage with visitors. The exhibition will take an innovative approach, allowing visitors to make links between the physical matter of the brain, the neurophysiology of its function, the mental processes this produces and the behaviours and culture this leads to. The exhibition will be developed in conjunction with researchers from Newcastle University's Institute of Neuroscience, led by Professor Anya Hurlbert, and colleagues within the region and beyond. By drawing links between disciplines, and between research in Newcastle and elsewhere, we want to capture the excitement of how research science works and foster pride in the local contribution to human knowledge. By linking the personal and local, to the global we hope to inspire interest and participation amongst a wider population.

grants.description: Mothers and their children participating in the WT-funded C-MaMiE birth cohort have received free healthcare at the point of use for the majority of the project duration; from recruitment (n=1065, recruited July 2005-March 2006) to be continued until the children are six years of age (July 2011-March 2012). Using the infrastructure of the Butajira Demographic Surveillance Site, we will recruit unbiased comparison birth cohorts of children and their mothers from the same community, who gave birth  in the months immediately before and after C-MaMiE recruitment, and who have not therefore been exposed to benefits of the C-MaMiE free healthcare intervention. This will enable us to conduct a quasi-experimental evaluation of the impact of relieving user fees on two key health public health outcomes in this rural Ethiopian setting: the prevalence of child stunting and cumulative mortality at six years. Using structural equation modelling, we will examine potential mediating pathways through po verty, maternal and child illness episodes and mental ill-health. The cost-effectiveness of the intervention in improving nutritional status and survival will be calculated. Qualitative investigation of the experience of health care costs and their alleviation, at the household level, will illuminate the relationship with help-seeking behaviours in response to illness.

grants.description: The mortality rate associated with adult bacterial meningitis (ABM) in Malawi is 54% and has not been impacted by two adjunctive interventions (Dexamethasone and Glycerol). Death from paediatric meningitis in Malawi has been reduced significantly using early antibiotics and specialist in hospital care. Resuscitation delivered through early goal directed therapy (EGDT) has shown a relative mortality reduction from adult sepsis in developed countries by 25% (Absolute Reduction 9%). We hypothesise that early resuscitation of adults with suspected ABM, using an EGDT bundle of interventions which are appropriate for resource limited settings, will significantly improve immediate and long term survival. Key goals: 1. We will test the bundle in a before/after study with sequentially phased prospective control and intervention groups in the new Wellcome Trust supported adult emergency and trauma centre (AETC) at Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The bundle will include nurse led rapid assessment and triage and targeted delivery of resuscitation to all subjects with suspected ABM using clear, achievable goal directed targets. Subjects will be excluded retrospectively if an alternative diagnosis is made subsequently. 2. We will assess the following study end points between the two groups: mortality (acute and at 6 weeks), neurological disability, epilepsy and hearing loss.

grants.description: The project aims initially to complete a database, begun by Dr Nicole Baur in 2007, of the principal information contained in around 10,000 mental health patients' files, dating from c 1870 to c 1970, received from Exe Vale Hospital(comprising Wonford House Hospital, the Devon County Lunatic Asylum at Exminster, and the Exeter City Asylum at Digby) in June 2006. This will be used to analyse the contents of the records, with a view to assessing their potential to support future research projects, and to establishing a rationalefor selection and retention of these files and other records from similar sources. (It is hoped that a parallel project, to be led by the Centre for Medical History at the University of Exeter, will also inform this process.) Files subsequently selected for permanent retention will be conserved when necessary, re-packaged, and given a permanent location at the Devon Record Office; the remainder will be confidentially destroyed. The records retained will be catalogued using CALM 2000 for Archives, and the catalogue will be made available on the Internet. The principal outcomes will be a corpus of records selected, preserved, and catalogued; support for a CMH medical recordsresearch project; a clear rationale for selection and preservation of patients' mental health files; and closer collaborative links with healthcare professionals and the research community.

grants.description:
Having completed the first phase of the successful Mental Health Care website, we now have an outstanding platform to further extend and develop this initiative and to engage the public to an even greater extent in the knowledge transfer about research findings from the Institute of Psychiatry, King's College London, and about the best available evidence on mental illnesss worldwide. We now intend to expand the website with users' and carers' input, to improve both the depth of the content and the range of carers included, and to extend substantially public participation activities in our research.

This project will aim to update the format of carer case stories (adding audio/video clips); produce new information for young carers in consultation with this group; involve carers in the research process via new mental health carer in research panels; encourage debate about topical issues in mental health and research; encourage the public to make comments on the website; extend the current coverage of research and evaluate the impact and reach of the website, via online surveys and feedback sessions with users. We will produce final published reports of these activities to summarise the project's conclusions, distributing them to the public and the research community, and publish them in peer-reviewed journals

We will also directly support the new national anti-stigma campaign in England, Moving People, to reduce the negative connotations and discrimination associated with mental illness as well as working to promote the website to a wider audience, including GPs, community centres, hospital and service users, using targeted publicity.

grantProgramme.description: Our Digital Participation Charter Fund, supported by by the Scottish Government, the ERDF and BT, invests in community digital participation projects across Scotland. grants.description: The proposed project is aimed at increasing the understanding, knowledge and experience about electronic participation and engagement for accessing Reach’s services and providing feedback on the services. The project will enhance their basic electronic communication skills and improve their social network skills.    The project will be delivered in Glasgow at the Reach premises. The beneficiaries are EM women mainly from a South Asian background.    1. In order to achieve the above aims Reach will, first of all, update the current website to make it more interactive.  This process will involve   a) creating an electronic booking system for the walking groups (5 walking groups with 64 members).  b) Mental Health counselling booking system to help clients book and cancel their appointments, to help counsellors manage their sessions and counselling partners (GP surgeries) access client progress.    c) Integrate Facebook, Twitter and Youtube into the Reach website.    2. Concurrently, Reach key staff will receive training on basic management and operation of the interactive sections of the website (external trainers)    3) Organise and deliver 8 workshops of 2 hours each with up to 10 participants in each group to help understand and use the interactive part of the Reach website and general use of social media including group text messaging such as Whatsapp.     4) The workshops will be complemented with hands on experience on using social media tools and using the Reach interactive website booking system.  This will involve 2 sessions of 1 hour each per individual with 5 in a group benefiting 80 individuals.  The practical sessions will be delivered at 2 libraries i.e. Govanhill Library and Ibrox Library.  The practical sessions will be delivered by Reach staff who are trained through external trainers (as mentioned). In addition to the set programmes above the service users will have the opportunity to contact Reach staff if they need support after the delivery of the project.    The proposed project is innovative in a sense that it has specific and predetermined areas to improve and digitise a specific group of EM individuals including service users. It will bring in external partners and make use of existing resources thereby providing better value for money (use of libraries for I.T. service plus the space for workshops).    The other innovative part is that it helps build the technological skills for up to 80 EM individuals in order to not just help their skills but also to help use Reach services (Mental Health Counselling, Employability, Health Walks). The project will build long term knowledge and skills about social media which will help them in future or to engage with others in the community including being able to access services from different agencies. The project also has a long term benefit i.e. by Reach being able to continue to help the service users in electronic engagement.

recipientOrganization.description: Disability Initiative (DI) is a charity and company limited by guarantee, which specialises in the provision of services to adults with complex physical disabilities and/ or acquired brain injury. DI supports service users with continuous assessment and monitoring, initially through the early stages of disability as the person and their family come to terms with such a radical change, and then through the provision of ongoing support. Everyone who attends DI as a client is also a member of the charity and has a stake in its activities, operations and strategic direction. DI specialises in providing care and slow stream rehabilitation to individuals that helps them achieve their goals, no matter how large or small. This is accomplished through a variety of activities, accredited educational courses and therapies unique to DI. Each programme is specifically designed to meet an individual's needs and aspirations. DI operates from a purpose-built centre that offers a fully accessible environment with easy access to Camberley town centre. The charity was established in 1975. It has 9 full-time staff, 7 part-time staff, 25 volunteers and a Management Committee of 6.
