recipientOrganization.name: Brentwood Community Print CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Brentwood Community Print: Established in 2011, Brentwood Community Print ( BCP) is a Community Interest Company with a wealth of local experience of working with and for people with mental health illnesses. The organisation exists to support people in recovery from mental ill health to gain confidence, skills and work experience in a safe and caring environment. Everyone at Brentwood Community Print including the Directors and staff has lived experience of mental ill health and support their peers in their own recovery journeys. In addition BCP have built up a good reputation through their outreach activities that include promotional campaigns involving the fictitious character "TED" who gained acclaim through our Lottery funded courses in 2015/16 with our confidence and empowerment courses to members of the public and "Good mental health in the workplace" presentations to local employers, including the Jobcentre and Brentwood Council middle management.They were honoured to be included in a case study and report produced for ACAS in late 2016 and are working with the University of Essex on the recommendations from this report in designing and presenting a workshop with circa 40 employers in 2017 with further work in the pipeline. This work will place BCP in a favourable position to reduce the stigma and discrimination that surrounds the subject of Mental illness and give us opportunities to inform a wider audience about the support available within their communities. Brentwood Community Tree In 2013, BCP set up The Brentwood Mental Health Providers Forum with the aim of working together with other mental health support agencies supporting people in Brentwood to provide and promote better mental health for residents. In 2015 the Forum became the Brentwood Community Tree Partnership. Led and managed by The Director of BCP, the partnership has worked together to create promotional materials and attend events and opportunities to promote the work of the organisations in the partnership.The Community Tree currently has 18 partner organisations and more waiting to join. Activities have included the design and production of 5000 "Who can I turn to" information leaflets, funded by Brentwood Council's Community Fund ( designed and produced by people in recovery from mental health illnesses at BCP), a presentation to GPs at a Time to Learn event, and to a patient engagement team. Plus a monthly information stand at Brentwood Library. The Community Tree has worked together to successfully identify a gap in peer support provision and in January 2016, opened a social inclusion ‘Colour Me IN Café’ based at the local theatre, for people with mental ill-health, other disabilities and the general public to attend and colour, whilst forming friendships with peers and volunteers from the Community Tree partner organisations. The Colouring books have been designed and produced by people in recovery from mental health illnesses who attend Brentwood Community Print . The books have a dual purpose also providing information and contact details of the organisations on the Community Tree. Attendance has been incredibly successful with some of the most vulnerable people in our community attending on a weekly basis giving the Community Tree exposure to those in most need of the services. Due to the success a further session will open early February helping the Community Tree to reach more vulnerable adults.

recipientOrganization.description: Contact the Elderly is dedicated to relieving the acute loneliness and isolation of older people aged 75 and over who live alone, without family, friends or other support networks nearby. We meet this need with a simple yet effective model: free, monthly tea parties for small groups of older people and volunteers within their community. Our model is a sustainable and scalable solution for the prevention and reduction of loneliness and social isolation providing strong and tangible outcomes for older people. It also provides opportunities to a large number of volunteers, providing them with training and development. Our work is rooted in local communities and led by volunteer group coordinators. By working closely with older people, many of whom enjoy our service for up to a decade, we understand how loneliness impacts on wellbeing, which helps to inform our work and plan our activities. We work with older people through key transition points in their lives and signpost to other services. We operate our model in the following ways: • Community groups: These take place on a Sunday when other services are unavailable and considered the loneliest day of the week for many. These groups form the core of our work. • University groups: This is a developing area of activity. Hosted by students, these aim to develop intergenerational relationships and raise awareness of the issues of isolation and loneliness in older people. • Special Interest Groups: These groups are offshoots of existing tea party groups and involve the interests of members. Examples include museums hosting tea parties and men only groups. • GP Groups: These groups are run by patient participation groups alongside GP’s. This is our newest area of work and we currently run 12 groups in the UK. Our target beneficiaries are isolated and lonely older people age 75+ living alone. In some areas of the UK, the target age group is 68-70 to account for lower life expectancies. Loneliness and isolation can have a devastating effect on mental health and wellbeing, impacting on physical health. The majority of those using our services fall into the 'oldest old' category; almost half (45%) of those attending tea parties are in their 80s, while 19% are in their 90s and 1% are over 100. Many have social care needs including mobility problems, hearing problems and visual impairment. Over two thirds (69%) of our older guests only receive visits from anyone other than a paid carer, just once a week or less. Almost half (44%)do not know their neighbours. For many of our older guests the tea party is the only social outing they attend each month. Some five million older people say TV is their main form of company. Loneliness can have a greater effect on overall health than obesity and heart disease. Lonely people drink more often and are prone to early admission to residential care. Loneliness and social isolation are considered as harmful as smoking 15 cigarettes a day*. Up to one in ten patients a day visit their GP because they are lonely. Global AgeWatch Index research published in Sept 2015 states that 1 in 10 older people describe themselves as being lonely often or all the time. Survey results recently published by The Jo Cox Commission on loneliness suggest this figure is even higher and that almost three-quarters of older people in the UK are lonely and more than half of those have never spoken to anyone about how they feel. Local authority services enabling people to maintain social networks have diminished or escalated significantly in cost, thus the essential roles monitoring welfare and early intervention support have significantly reduced for many older people. Tea parties create inter-generational friendships and often involve whole families. Many guests and volunteers form strong friendships and networks develop around guests, providing informal monitoring of their welfare and contact outside of tea parties. We collect regular feedback and comments from guests, volunteers and referrers. Independent research carried out in 2016 amongst 700 older guests confirmed that the charity’s tea parties significantly relieve feelings of isolation and loneliness. This increases wellbeing and research showed as a direct result of tea parties we are meeting our outcomes: • 77% feel happier because of tea parties • 40% of our guests said that their physical or mental health has improved as a result of the tea parties • 95% said they have something to look forward to • 63% feel part of a community • 90% have made friends with volunteers and 81% with other guests. Volunteers work within their communities and their views and ideas are invaluable to us: • 23% of our volunteers have been with Contact the Elderly for between 6-40 years and 50% for between 1-5 years. • 21% heard about us through 'word of mouth' and 13% through local newspapers indicating our reach within communities. • 84% said their primary motivation for volunteers was 'wanting to help isolated and lonely older people' and Contact the Elderly provides them with regular opportunities to do this. Because our groups meet at the weekends, those who work and those that volunteers that also experience loneliness at the weekend particularly benefit. The third biggest reason for volunteering was 'feeling closer to my local community' with 22% of respondents citing this reason. • 30% of our volunteers also volunteer for very local organisations and provide vital links between Contact the Elderly and these groups. There is great value to volunteering within the communities we work in and of our volunteers: • 92% said 'I feel I am giving something back' • 77% said 'I am more aware of the issues facing older people' • 77% said 'I have made friends with an older person' • 71% said 'I feel a part of the community I live in' • 93% said they felt equipped by Contact the Elderly to help the older guests.
recipientOrganization.name: Contact The Elderly

recipientOrganization.description: Open Road is a registered charity with a strong and dynamic track record built up over 27 years. Our mission is to empower a diverse range of individuals, families and communities to lead healthy and more meaningful lives, free from addiction, offending behaviour and disadvantage, to ensure healthier, happier lifestyles. With over 100 staff and over 270 volunteers, we work across Essex from centres in Clacton, Colchester, Chelmsford, Harlow and Basildon and across Norfolk, Suffolk and Medway. We also operate outreach services at 28 different sites, working alongside families, carers, GP surgeries and hospitals. In 2016/17, over 10,500 people with drug and alcohol problems directly benefitted from the services we deliver. Open Road have been successfully working with drug users for over 27 years enabling individuals to break the cycle of addiction and get their lives, and those of their families, back on track and into recovery. Service users are able to access services through a number of ways, including self-referral, GP’s, Criminal Justice agencies, housing associations, other voluntary organisations. As an organisation we embrace the ‘no wrong door’ philosophy. Working within local communities we are acutely aware of the problems that individuals and families face linked to substance misuse. Open Road staff and volunteers work daily with problematic drug users offering treatment and providing counselling, therapy, benefits and housing advice, debt management, creative activities and employment support. Through providing help with access to training, volunteering, education and employment opportunities, Open Road works to ensure that people fully re-integrate into society and ultimately attain a meaningful way of life. Open Road have run the Colchester SOS bus for 10 years and have recently taken part in a successful pilot to deliver an SOS service in Chelmsford. As a result of the pilot we will now be delivering the service on a permanent basis from April 2017. The SOS bus projects work to support the night time economy, and help to keep the town and city centres safe on weekend nights. The SOS Bus has a primary role to provide a safe haven for any vulnerable person, irrespective of their age, race, sexual orientation or religion. The services operate between 8:30pm and 4:00am every Friday, Saturday and Bank Holidays' Sunday nights in Colchester and Chelmsford Town and City Centres. It is the first point of contact for any person who is at risk. We provide medical and emotional support to anyone who gets into difficulty. The SOS Bus team provide support to those in need. Volunteers are in place to provide welfare support, respect confidentiality, and be a calming influence. Our volunteers directly help any visitors to the bus and if needed, will contact other services to provide further assistance. Volunteers support the on-board medics assisting them where needed. The SOS project provides a safe space for individuals and supports them in getting home safely without any issues. In the case of young people visiting the bus for assistance, our volunteers contact the young person's parents to reassure them that their child is safe and arrange for the young person to be collected or be safely dropped off at home. The SOS Bus also provides free bottles of water and medical care, as well as advice and information to visitors. The service proactively reduces the need to involve Police and Paramedics, and has significantly reduced the number of local A&E visits. The service also works in partnership with local businesses, pubs and clubs to ensure that the town centre is a safer place for weekend revellers.   In addition to our core substance misuse services, we run other projects including: The Essex Appropriate Adult service, ensuring that young people and vulnerable adults are supported through the police custody process. This project relies on our dedicated volunteer Appropriate Adults, who give their time free of charge to be available to support young people and vulnerable adults people in custody, ensuring that their welfare rights are adhered to at all times, 365 days per year from 7am to 11pm. Indeed this service has been so successful because of the dedication of our Appropriate Adults volunteers, we now provide an on call service between 11pm - 7am, 365 days per year for serious crimes. We provide a mentoring project in Norfolk and Suffolk, and a women's service in Essex in partnership with the Community Rehabilitation Companies, providing volunteer mentors to those who are part of the criminal justice system. Again, this project is driven by volunteers, supported by paid Service Coordinators, who mentor probationers allowing them to reintegrate into society, to ensure that they do not fall back into offending behaviour patterns. We provide counselling, anger management and drug and alcohol awareness training to the Military Correction Training Centre (MCTC). Our qualified counselling team support detainees who have recognised that they need help dealing with drug and alcohol issues or with anger issues. Detainees accessing this very successful service often come from difficult backgrounds or have had challenging upbringings, leading to these issues in adult life. Common feedback from the detainees is that they can't believe it took them being detained to receive the support they so desperately needed around the various issues they have struggled with. The success of this service has meant that, this year, we were awarded the new contract to continue to provide the service until 2019, having provided this service for the last 10 years. We provide a Young People’s Drug and Alcohol services e in Medway both in the community and at HM YOI Cookham Wood. This service proactively helps and supports young people in the Medway area, who are experiencing various issues involving drug and alcohol abuse. The Medway team actively work with the local schools, undertaking visits and making presentations to the students, which has proved very successful in increasing student awareness of the dangers of drugs and alcohol misuse and leading to many young people accessing our services.

recipientOrganization.name: Lads Need Dads CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Who we are: Lads Need Dads CIC is a Not-For-Profit Community Interest Company, based in Tendring, North East Essex, set up to prevent potential problems and address existing ones where boys are missing a father figure in their lives. Our Mission: To empower and enable boys aged 11-15 with absent fathers or limited access to a male role model, to be motivated, responsible, capable, resilient and emotionally competent to prevent them from coming at risk of under achieving, offending, exclusion or dropping out of school. What we do: • Help boys through male-led group mentoring, to cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. • Provide boys with opportunities for adventure, to be tested and challenged, both physically and mentally. • Provide boys with practical life-skill training, community volunteering and peer mentoring opportunities. • Raise awareness and understanding of the important role fathers play in the emotional, mental and educational development and well-being of boys. Why we do it: In 2013 the Centre for Social Justice published Fractured Families: Why stability matters, which highlighted an alarming trend of fatherlessness across the UK. It found that a teenager sitting their GCSEs is more likely to own a smartphone than live with their father, (only 57 per cent of 15-year olds are still living with their fathers while 62 per cent own a smartphone), (1). Nationally almost one quarter of families with dependent children are lone-parent families. (2) This figure rises significantly in our poorest neighbourhoods, and can be as high as 75 percent. (3) Blanden (2006) (4), found a father’s low interest in his son’s education, for instance, reduces his boy’s chances of escaping poverty by 25% and at the more extreme end, 76% of all male prisoners in England and Wales had an absent father. Statistically males are the more vulnerable gender when it comes to alcohol and drug misuse, victims of murder, victims of suicide, homelessness. Lads Need Dads was set up to provide a preventative and early-intervention response to an ever-increasing social issue. Our services: ‘EQUIP’, is a six-month self-development group-work programme held in school including bush-craft and outdoor activities supported by a facilitator and a team of male mentors. Equips’ aim is to help boys cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. Engage, a practical life-skill and community volunteering programme follows Equip and takes place in the community for six-months and involves boys attending practical life-skill workshops and together with thier mentors, doing voluntary work for lone parents, pensioners and people with a disability within their local community. Jobs include, DIY, painting and decorating, gardening, shed building, etc. Inspire, a peer mentoring programme incorporating inspirational speakers and visits to inspiring places, completes the 18-month programme. We have run the 18-month pilot once through between March 2016 and August 2017 with excellent outcomes. We started another Equip Programme in May this year. This ended this month (Nov) and the boys off this programme are now attending Engage, the second part of the programme. Alongside the programme we provide on-going support for mums and carers via workshops, coffee mornings and a face-book support group. We raise awareness within the community by giving talks and presentations to community groups, attending public events etc. We run an open-ended check-in group for graduates of the programme one evening a month to keep the arm of support in place, should they need it. We run a fishing club in the summer which is open to any boy on the programme, graduate or new boy who fits our criteria. We are just about to start a guitar club for boys who want to learn to play the guitar but who can't afford lessons. All our services are provided free of charge. We have a growing team of 14 male volunteer male mentors, between the ages of 29 and 70, from a wide range of backgrounds and from the local community. Our Director board is made up of four professionals from education, social care, statutory services and the voluntary sector. We are just entering into our next round of recruitment so anticipate our volunteer numbers increasing. References: (1) Ibid, Ofcom, Children and Parents: Media User and Attitudes Report, 2013 (2) Office of National Statistics, General Lifestyle Survey Overview: A Report on the General Lifestyle Survey 2011, Chapter 3 – Households, families and people, 7 March 2013 [accessed via: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/dcp171776_302210.pdf (2/7/14)] (3) Centre for Social Justice, Fractured Families: Why stability matters, London: Centre for Social Justice, 2013, p32. (4) Blanden, J. (2006). ‘Bucking the trend’: What enables those who are disadvantaged in childhood to succeed later in life? Working Paper No 31 Corporate Document Services. London: Department for Work and Pensions. (5) Prison Reform Trust 2015.

recipientOrganization.name: The MAZE Group CiC
recipientOrganization.description: The MAZE is a unique approach, which offers an insight into how children with additional needs experience the world around them in order that parents can better understand their children and why they respond in the way that they do. Specifically, the MAZE Approach examines these 3 key areas of difficulty for additional needs: • Sensory Processing Difficulties that 95% of ASD children experience and that can explain many unusual or challenging behaviours. • Communication difficulties that the children experience, which are often not detected even if they present with functional, fluent speech. • Social Understanding and an exploration of how an impaired ability to make social sense of situations leads to social difficulties, with a focus on the value of Social Stories. We offer training in the Maze Approach to parents, schools and other professionals. In the training for parents (which is what we are asking for partial funding for) we cover: The topics covered are: •Session 1: Introductions •Session 2: Sensory Processing Difficulties •Session 3: Communication Strategies •Session 4: Social Understanding •Session 5: Lifestyle issues (sleep, continence, diet) •Session 6: Behaviour Management - using positive strategies Session 7: Positive Family Relationships •Session 8: Behaviour Management - limit setting and consequences •Session 9: Functional Behaviour Analysis •Session 10: My Childs Development •Session 11: What about me? Building resilience •Session 12: Planning For The Future - moving on Our service users are the parents and carers of children with additional needs. This may be a learning difficulty, physical disability, autism, ADHD, cerebral palsy or any other additional or special need. We have worked with parents of children with a wide range of difficulties. Many parents do not have sufficient knowledge about their child's condition and are not provided with this information on diagnosis. They are often socially isolated because of their child's difficulties, which commonly include challenging behaviour and they also struggle to access appropriate activities out of school hours. These families experience further difficulties with accessing the appropriate education and support for their child, which can result in school exclusions or tribunals. Additionally, the families face difficulties in accessing services such as O/T, speech therapy or short breaks/services through Social Care and also face very restricted leisure opportunities Here’s what our parents have to say about it: “My life changed. I was lost and I didn’t know what to do. After Maze I have the tools that I need to help myself and my child. My child is happier. Less arguments in my household. Siblings are happy and not fighting.” “My son has noticed positive changes to his and my relationship as a result of alterations to our lifestyle…I’ve learned so many positive strategies from Sue and other guests and attendees to use at home, and feel very supported.” “[I have] a better understanding of how my daughter thinks, giving me methods to deal with challenging situations…we’re a lot happier.” “It helped me understand my daughter more… I see people I can relate with and felt I am not alone. This session is making me strong….best course I have ever done for my daughter and myself.” “I feel better able to communicate with my child confidently.” We have a hundreds of feedback forms filled with comments like this and 99.6% of parents highly recommend the MAZE.

recipientOrganization.description: Adfam was founded by the mother of a heroin user who found that the support that she and other family members needed was simply not available. Families are often the unheard and unseen victims when a loved one uses drugs or alcohol, and on top of the physical and psychological strains, they must struggle to get the support they need. We continue to exist for, and are led by the needs of, family members and carers who cannot find the support they require from any other agency. Adfam is the only national umbrella organisation working to improve the quality of life for family members affected by someone else’s drug and/or alcohol use. We provide them with direct and indirect support – including providing emotional support and opportunities for respite for family carers; giving practical advice, information, signposting and advocacy; development assistance for community organisations setting up peer support groups for family members; training for practitioners working with family members; briefings to press and policy-makers outlining the desperate need for support for family members; factsheets and reports published on our website; and printed leaflets and information booklets disseminated through partners and at events. Adfam works with and for families affected by substance misuse. All of our practice is informed by the needs expressed to us by the families we work with. We aim to: • make sure that family members get the support that they require to recover from the impact of substance misuse in their lives • reduce the social isolation and powerlessness felt by family members and carers of people who misuse drugs and/or alcohol, in the face of shame and stigma • ensure that family members’ voices are heard in the debate around support for people with substance misuse problems.
recipientOrganization.name: Adfam National

recipientOrganization.description: Lanarkshire Deaf Club provides support and advice for deaf people of all ages. We are volunteer led. This includes running and organising the social club for the deaf community and their families, a mother and toddler group during school holidays, a youth group and the formation of a 'drop in' service. We provide an opportunity for deaf families to have a safe environment where both hearing and deaf people are equal. During the mother's group we teach baby sign. In the future we will be restarting BSL sign language courses. The 'drop in' service is a service that the deaf community can access for assistance with correspondance, appointments or to be sign posted to the appropriate service ensuring that there is an appropriately qualified interpreter there. The service is aimed at all age groups and ethnicity. We support both deaf people with hearing children and hearing people with deaf children.
recipientOrganization.name: Lanarkshire Deaf Club

grants.description: We aim to provide an employment support to enable the Deaf community to access welfare advice and support to seek employment by using their first language of British Sign Language. There is no service in place to provide support for the deaf community in the area. With welfare reform and lack of employment opportunity this is leading to deterioration in many families and individuals mental health. The communication barrier faced by many Deaf in our society is a huge hurdle that needs to be addressed. Rather than valuable members of our society being left at home we need to put things in place to enable them to access and have the same rights as their hearing counterparts. We already have strong links with other advice agencies such as North Lanarkshire Disability Forum and CAB. Through these links we would be able to signpost and provide the much-needed advice to the Deaf community. Our communication support worker will be there to translate from BSL to English. Within the Deaf community there is a very high unemployment rate. This was highlighted in the information gathering in the lead up to the British Sign Language (Scotland) Act 2015 being approved. Many young Deaf and deaf families live in poverty and are unaware of changes to the welfare system due to nothing being sent out in their own language of BSL. There have been many changes in how to access information and apply for jobs. Many companies now choose to put their applications online. Many Deaf people cannot access this as they cannot understand written English and cannot afford to have Internet at home. We aim to provide a service where Deaf people can come and have help in accessing application forms, making phone calls on their behalf and assisting with welfare benefits advice.
grants.title: LDC - Employment and Welfare Service
grants.recipientLocation: S13003060 Motherwell South East and Ravenscraig Ward S12000044 Scotland North Lanarkshire

recipientOrganization.description: Saha is a charitable provider of social housing and support services across England. The Association is registered under the Co-operative and Community Benefit Societies Act 2014 (registration no. 15210R) and the Homes and Communities Agency (registration no. LH 2429). Saha provides accommodation for a range of different people, young and old. Our support services help people to develop their personal talents, flourish and live independently. Our principal activities are the development and management of social housing, primarily for single people. This includes Lifehouses for homeless people, Foyers offering support and training and housing with appropriate support services for vulnerable people. Braintree Foyer is managed and owned by the Salvation Army Housing Association. The Foyer provides accommodation, support and training for 35 people aged 18 – 35 who have experienced homelessness. Braintree Foyer was officially opened in November 1994 as the first purpose built foyer in the UK. Since it opened the foyer has provided accommodation, support and training for over 1000 young people from the Braintree District. In recent years the foyer has been increasingly recognised as an exceptional service and was only the second service ever to receive the Foyer Federation Transformational Innovation Award. In 2016 Braintree Foyer was a finalist of the Essex ‘Who Will Care’ Innovation Award. Over the past 6 years the Foyer has had an 86% success rate of young people making a positive move on from the foyer. The foyer is always fully occupied and has a waiting list. Braintree Foyer regularly receives visits from international organisations who want to learn about the foyer service. At the last service review undertaken by Essex County Council, Braintree Foyer was commended as, ‘showing how innovative and creative ideas can support young people to reach goals. The service has a ‘can do’ attitude and approach and is very warm and welcoming to both service users and the wider community. The staff are engaged and committed to the work they do with their young people and encourage individual learning with an aim to develop independent living skills. Management are focused and open to experiment with new innovative ideas that can assist in developing the above. The service shares good practice with other partners and has an open door policy to share the services good practice’. Braintree Foyer residents come to us from very chaotic backgrounds, having suffered abuse, family breakdown or substance misuse and have been sleeping rough or sofa surfing. Our residents also include care leavers, young people with learning difficulties and mental health issues; they are vulnerable young adults with low self-esteem who find it hard to see a positive future. Many take prescription anti-depressants and self-harming is common. However Braintree Foyer is a service which sees the potential in all young people and which focuses on the person rather than the problem. We challenge young people to be the best that they possibly can by nurturing and promoting young people’s talents and aspirations. Braintree Foyer also supports many young people from the local community through its project work including: Braintree Discovery College Braintree Discovery College was launched in April 2015 to provide a broad curriculum of free courses with the aim of reigniting a love of learning in people who have experienced disadvantage in their lives. Braintree Discovery College removes the barriers to learning and empowers young people take control of their own personal development. Braintree Discovery College offers courses which are completely on the learners own terms and as a result it has been very successful in engaging hard to reach young people. Courses are delivered by volunteers from the local community and further afield. We have high calibre volunteer tutors at the Discovery College including academics, CEO's, authors, campaigners and people who will inspire our young people such as the Paralympian Anne Wafula Strike and the former world champion natural bodybuilder Alun Davies. Since the launch in 2015 over 400 young people have enrolled as students of Braintree Discovery College and more than 1200 sessions have been delivered. Braintree Foyer Community Gym Braintree Foyer Community Gym was opened in 2010 to offer a fully equipped free gym for young people who live at the foyer and people from our local community. Since then more than 300 people have used the gym and completed gym inductions and personal training plans with our gym instructors. At any one time there are 70+ regular active users of the gym. In addition to personal training the Gym offers fitness boot camps, circuit training and the 'Ladies that Lift' Programme which encourages young women to use weight training as part of their excercise. The people from the local community who use our gym are people who would be unable to afford gym memberships at commercial gyms. The Foyer is committed to improving the health and wellbeing of young people. Braintree Sound Academy Braintree Sound Academy was established in 2012 to offer free music workshops and live gigs for young people from Braintree District. The project offers workshops 3 evenings per week and intensive week long courses during the school holidays. Workshops include guitar lessons, drum lessons, singing, sound recording, sound engineering, song writing and DJ and MC workshops At the end of each course is a live gig and since 2012 more than 10,000 people have seen young people from Braintree Sound Academy perform at music festivals, Bocking Arts Theatre and even the Royal Opera House.

recipientOrganization.description: Outside the Box is a small charity based in Glasgow that works with community groups across Scotland. We were established in 2004 and the aims are to advance people’s health and wellbeing, and to support participation and citizenship. We deliver services that are planned and led by the people who use those services, to establish new types of support and bring services to areas where there are gaps. We work with people who get support to develop Tips and other resources that can be used locally and through websites to provide support to a much larger number of people. The people with whom we work are mostly those affected by disadvantage or who feel that they do not have a voice. They include older people, people with disabilities, people with mental health problems and people affected by addictions.
recipientOrganization.name: Outside The Box Development Support Limited

grants.description: This will be an extension of the Falkirk Food Buddies project. The current project involves setting up peer support for older people in Falkirk around issues with food. This project would allow us to expand the service to incorporate more issues, using food as an incentive, a mechanism for forging relationships, a learning tool and confidence builder. We would run a drop in self-help sessions in the West of Falkirk Council Area for people over 50 on low incomes. This part of the demographic makes up 24% of all people claiming unemployment benefits in Falkirk. West of Falkirk is recognised as a cold spot for support services and recent bus routes cancellations made it even harder for people to access the support they need. The self-help sessions will be facilitated by a paid worker and will address issues faced by the participants. When necessary, an outside representative may be brought in, to provide relevant information- for example welfare advice or Mental Health 1st Aid training. This project offers us a chance to work in partnership with other local organisations, such as Falkirk District Association for Mental Health and local Citizens Advice Bureau. The sessions will be initially led by the worker, but the participants will be encouraged to take an equally active role, eventually taking over the running of the sessions once the funded period ends. This way the project should become sustainable. Food will be available at each session to encourage participation and to spread the message about the importance of food, both as a source of nutrition and as a way of connecting with other people. Some of the food will need to be prepared by the participants, as a way of increasing confidence and skills around food and as a way of augmenting social connections between them.

recipientOrganization.name: West Dunbartonshire Community Foodshare
recipientOrganization.description: WDCF began distributing emergency food parcels to those in need in March 2013. We are currently supporting around 110 people per week. We receive food donations from local supermarkets, businesses and members of the public. We have current partnerships with local organisations including advice agencies, mental health charities, Womens Aid, homelessness charities, drug and alcohol charities, schools and colleges and council services. We have a main storage/office unit as well as operating 3 distribution points across West Dunbartonshire: Clydebank, Dumbarton & Alexandria. WDCF also operate a backtoschool uniform bank and Christmas Toybank. We are currently solely ran by a dedicated team of volunteers from differing backgrounds which include individuals who were previously WDCF service users.

grants.description: When people present at any of our three weekly foodbanks we will support them to make contact with one of the advice services in the area ie., citizens advice bureau/welfare rights. We will devise an action plan which will ensure that, while they receive the relevant support and advice to resolve the issue (debt, benefit sanctions etc.,), they receive practical support from Foodshare. We will put in place a support package including emergency food parcels and provision of new skills like cooking low-cost nutritional food and growing their own produce. We will equip individuals with the skills to live independantly of foodbank provision once the identified issue is resolved. We will strengthen our current partnerships with the local advice/support agencies to ensure those in need can access the relevant support to resolve financial difficulties and maximise benefit income. Many of our current service users report they have had difficulties accessing services. We will hold sessions where individuals/families can come together socially to learn how to cook using low energy (slow cookers) and low cost produce (cheaper cuts of meat). We will provide recipe cards and weekly menu planners to equip families to eat healthy, nutritious food whilst on a low income. We will share skills and knowledge of growing your own produce, further reducing weekly shopping bills, demonstrating how to grow using grow sacks and hanging baskets for those with no land/garden space. We will purchase slow cookers (£10) which individuals will take home at the end of the month, to be able to implement the new skills and knowledge into their daily living. We currently receive donations of food which we will be able to use in cooking sessions, but will need to purchase low cost meat. Examples of the dishes we will cook include meats, pastas and soups.
grants.title: Community Nourish

recipientOrganization.description: Fledglings Family Services design and source practical, affordable, good quality products and solutions to everyday problems experienced by children with physical and learning disabilities and health conditions. Our Helpline service team offer emotional support and practical help and we source, supply and design items that help children, for example, to learn to feed independently, become toilet trained, to sit, to stand, to walk, to play, to swim, to access education and to keep children safe from harm. The Helpline team is experienced at providing sensitive emotional support and parents frequently 'open up' over the phone about issues that they would be uncomfortable discussing face-to-face. As one parent said of Fledglings, "We love that there is somewhere we can find solutions to our problems rather than confused faces! You make us feel nearly normal!" Fledglings primary purpose in trading is to meet the need of the child and family at the best possible price. We focus on meeting individual need as far as it is possible. Our voluntary income and volunteer labour is what makes this possible, as these, in effect, subsidise the cost of the item. Our objectives are to: • Increase the independence, physical and mental well-being of children living with disabilities and ill-health conditions • Support children with disabilities to achieve their educational and developmental potential • Help children with disabilities and their families/carers to experience greater inclusion in all aspects of everyday life such as education, leisure, recreation and healthcare. • Inform, facilitate and empower families/carers to support their children and each other. • Help health/social care professional to better support the child patients and families/carers. • Enable low income families to access our services and products. We co-ordinate a recycling service so that families can donate or sell at low cost items in good condition that might otherwise go to landfill. Our helpline team also identify additional funding sources for low income families. What makes us unique? Businesses supplying products suitable for disabled children and adults are often only supplying one type of item and are often driven by commercial factors which do not take account of individual need. Disability charities supplying products suitable for disabled children generally do so largely as a means of raising income to support other services. Fledglings gives families the opportunity to purchase most of what they need from one source, saving time and money. “So great to be able to get so many things we need from just one place". We also keep stocks of many small inexpensive items that can make all the difference to children but are generally only available in packs. By dividing packs we give parents the chance, with minimum financial outlay, to try an individual item to test its effectiveness. Many families come back time-after-time to purchase items from us as their children grow. One of our social worker users tells us: “The thing that makes your service stand out from any other is that you understand the needs of our families and that you are willing to go the extra mile to source items and remedy individual needs which no other organisation can do!” From a home-based organisation helping local children and families we have now grown into a national charity helping over 26,000 families a year in every region of the UK (up from 23,000 last year). This growth continues. Families find us through google searches, via word of mouth and through referrals from a wide range of health, education and social care professionals including paediatricians, occupational therapists, speech therapists, GP’s, practice nurses, portage workers, social workers, disability teams, children’s centres, school SEN officers, patient groups and disability charities. Due to our origins and location we are pleased to support a larger number of people in Essex than in other parts of the UK. Currently approximately 1306 families, carers and professionals in Essex are supported by Fledglings (increasing from 952 last year) and accounting for 4.98% of all families. As a proportion of the overall running costs (projected at £411164 in 2017-2018) the cost of supporting families in Essex is approximately £20,475. A recent example of how we have helped a family in Essex is given below; X contacted us in August 2016 to see if we could offer help and advice for her son Y referred from Grove Cottage. Her son has an undiagnosed genetic abnormality, global developmental delay, hyper mobility and is non-verbal. X’s main concern is her son’s severe head banging and his sensory issues. Y has no sense of danger and a very high pain threshold and will bruise and hurt himself so badly that he has to wear a helmet 24/7.Y doesn’t sleep well and recently put his head through a wall when he got out of bed . Y will also rock obsessively, especially at meal times when he is in his high chair. This makes feeding him hard. and pulling at his mother’s hair. Fledglings provided detailed information and advice on safe options for sleeping, a safe and secure high chair that he cannot rock, a safe car seat, secure walking reins, products to help with teeth brushing, a large special needs buggy, sensory toys and solutions, and therapies that are available. We also recommended funding programmes to help towards the cost of the products, therapies and hospital visits. We made a follow up call to X in May 2017 to ask how she was getting on. Things have improved for X. More teams became involved with her family and funding has been secured for the padded room which has, in X’s words, been ‘life changing’. Y is much happier, he is sleeping through the night, he is less tired, doesn’t bang his head as much and is now much more affectionate – ‘a different little boy’. The high chair has helped Y to feed better and the changes in the family situation have been a ‘miracle’. Y is a different boy who will be attending a special school soon.
recipientOrganization.name: Fledglings Family Services

grants.description: This application aims to obtain the fund to build a new fish facility at KCL, Guy s campus. The campus has an existing fish facility hosting 12,000 fish. The exponential increase of our zebrafish users, the growing need for mutant and transgenic lines and the age-related deterioration of the existing facility require the urgent implementation of a new, bigger, space-effective state of the art facility. The KCL zebrafish research community has become the largest in the UK and include some of the  most productive labs in the field. The facility as it stands is currently unable to meet the demands of KCL users. Moreover, the oldest and much larger of the two rooms has recently developed irreversible aging problems that will undoubtedly lead to future severe restriction in the maintenance of our resources with disastrous impact on research, if a new aquarium system is not installed in a very near future. The new and bigger facility will be built in a new space and will replace the existin g old room, providing better quality resources (hosting a max. of 40,000 fish) and supporting the implementation of new mutants and transgenics essential to maintain a competitive and world-leading zebrafish research.

recipientOrganization.name: Foundation for Art and Creative Technology (Fact)

grants.description: Group Therapy is FACT's 2015 spring exhibition exploring mental health through the work of contemporary artists. As part of this, we are seeking support from Wellcome Trust to realise Madlove, an exciting participatory installation created by artist The Vacuum Cleaner. Madlove invites the public to help imagine a designer asylum, and asks the question: If you could design your own psychiatric hospital what would it be like? It considers the current social and medical perception of mental heal th. As part of the R&D process, The Vacuum Cleaner team is currently holding participatory workshops across the UK with both patients and professionals. The stories, ideas and knowledge collected will be used to develop a blueprint for the creation of a temporary asylum in Liverpool at FACT - a pilot for a future larger scale intervention. During the exhibition, we will activate the space with talks and workshops led by patients, neurologists, nurses, psychologists, doctors, and thinkers fro m across the fields of psychology, health and society. Madlove has been developed by artist James Leadbitter a disabled artist who has experienced severe depression, chronic anxiety, panic attacks, and borderline personality disorder. James has been admitted to psychiatric wards many times during the past 14 years and believes that a new model is needed. Group Therapy is being developed in partnership with professionals from across the academic and health sectors, including Principal Cons ultant Professor Peter Kinderman, Head of the Institute of Psychology, Health and Society at the University of Liverpool.

grants.description: The mortality rate associated with adult bacterial meningitis (ABM) in Malawi is 54% and has not been impacted by two adjunctive interventions (Dexamethasone and Glycerol). Death from paediatric meningitis in Malawi has been reduced significantly using early antibiotics and specialist in hospital care. Resuscitation delivered through early goal directed therapy (EGDT) has shown a relative mortality reduction from adult sepsis in developed countries by 25% (Absolute Reduction 9%). We hypothesise that early resuscitation of adults with suspected ABM, using an EGDT bundle of interventions which are appropriate for resource limited settings, will significantly improve immediate and long term survival. Key goals: 1. We will test the bundle in a before/after study with sequentially phased prospective control and intervention groups in the new Wellcome Trust supported adult emergency and trauma centre (AETC) at Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The bundle will include nurse led rapid assessment and triage and targeted delivery of resuscitation to all subjects with suspected ABM using clear, achievable goal directed targets. Subjects will be excluded retrospectively if an alternative diagnosis is made subsequently. 2. We will assess the following study end points between the two groups: mortality (acute and at 6 weeks), neurological disability, epilepsy and hearing loss.

grants.description: Despite the growing research evidence on the burden of mental disorders and the cost-effectiveness of treatments for mental disorders, the 'treatment gaps' remain very large in developing countries. One of the major barriers in facilitating the scaling up of services is the marginalised voices of people affected by mental disorders and the limited capacity of groups representing them (?user organizations?) to articulate positions based on science. The aim of this proposal is to strengthen the capacity of user organizations in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia to utilise research findings to develop a plan for engagement with the wider community to improve the understanding of the nature and treatment of mental disorders and reduce the pervasive INT ENGAGEMENT AWARD FORM 01/08 Page 6 of 23 stigma associated with these conditions. This project will achieve its objectives through a series of linked activities: participation of each user organization in the annual Leadership in Mental Health course in Goa, India in November 2010 where the participants will interact with researchers and practitioners to develop the key messages for the communication strategy; developing the communication strategy around these key messages, contextualised for each setting; increasing the acceptability of the Movement for Global Mental Health (MGMH) website, and the partner organization web-sites, for non-professional audiences, with technical support from web-design experts; and dissemination of the communication strategies through the websites and presentation at the Global Mental Health Summit in Cape Town in October 2011. Ultimately, the strategies will be the basis for concerted campaigns in each country to call for action to achieve the goals of the MGMH.

grants.description: The main aim of this project is to write a cultural history of the movement led by Franco Basaglia in favour of mental health reform in Italy in the 1960s and 1970s and to look at the legacy of that movement in terms of both the services on offer today and the memory and representation of the past.  The project will carry out research into the cultural and political history of this movement, its local differences and policies and the ways in which it has been represented and remembered over  time. My research will utilise interviews, documents and detailed local studies to tell its story. It will examine a number of case studies in detail, the theories adopted by Basaglia s followers - the 'Basagliani' (as they became known)  -  international links and the debates within the movement, as well as criticisms from outside and the political context. The project will also look into developments in mental health reform since the 1970s, the representation of the Basaglia movement i n film, literature and art and the fate of the ex-mental health asylums today (as ruins, as memory, as sites of forgetting).

grants.description: The initial aim of this project is to synthesise a small library of ATP-mimetics and probe the heterogeneous ATP binding pockets of the 8 CCT subunits. The compounds will first be tested in steady state ATPase assays (Shimon et al; 2008) and an activity series assembled. Selected molecules would then be used in a chemical genetics screen against yeast CCT and ATP-site mutants in various of its subunits. Recent work in the Willison laboratory has led to an X-ray crystal structure for yeast CCT which is of sufficiently high resolution to guide the design of mutants. This will allow a level of understanding of this complex molecular machine which has not been achieved by any other approach. If time permits, the understanding gained of both the biology of CCT and the small molecules will be used to develop drug-like inhibitors of human CCT.

recipientOrganization.description: OTR is a mental health movement for young people by young people aged 11-25 across Bristol and South Gloucestershire. Our mission is to support, promote and defend the mental health, rights and social position of young people. We are a self-referral organisation aimed at early intervention and prevention with no service thresholds. We support around 3000 individuals each year. A further 7000 are reached through our programme of health promotion, psychological education and activism. Because of this, the range of young people and issues we see is as diverse as the city itself. As well as direct mental health support (various forms of one-to-one and group therapy, mentoring, key working, coaching) and health promotion/education (the focus of which is our peer education project, The Resilience Lab, which in-reaches to schools delivering workshops on self-care), our other key areas of work include community development, social action (our Mentality Project is made up of young volunteers with lived experience of mental ill-health campaigning for less stigma and better services), and training for professionals and parents. All our work is psychosocial and assets based in character. Young people and parents are resources and participants at OTR, not just service users.

recipientOrganization.description: Rainbow Services works to alleviate the effects of disadvantage, deprivation and social exclusion through imaginative projects that support, enable and develop people and organisations and which stimulate beneficial change in the local community and beyond. We do this through the following current initiatives: - Rainbow Services provides infrastructure support to local voluntary and community groups, holding regular meetings and publishing a weekly e-bulletin sharing information on subjects relevant to the sector, giving advice and guidance, delivering workshops on topics such as GDPR, and facilitating a voluntary sector hub with affordable room hire and office space. In 16/17 we sent 50 e-briefings out to over 200 organisations; - Rainbow Services also provides direct services to the local community via our Community Builder project, which is currently supporting local older residents. across Harlow who are socially isolated. This project uses an Asset Based Community Development approach to work with older people to develop sustainable social groups, supported by volunteers, and co-ordinate safety and health information sessions combined with social opportunities. In 16/17 over 900 older people were supported ; -Our Business Engagement project is working to facilitate a more structured approach to Corporate Social Responsibility and to create a better pipeline for business involvement and volunteering opportunities with the wider Voluntary Sector and local community, in partnership with Harlow Chamber of Commerce. Started in August 2017, the project has already engaged with 17 VCSE and 5 business organisations and is in the process of matching 6 volunteer opportunities; - Our Workshop project is a contracted arrangement (with Sodexo) to provide a workplace environment for offenders who have received a community service order through the courts in an environment that is, whilst punitive, also rehabilitative and constructive. This project is the only community and voluntary sector run programme which Sodexo offers in Essex and is creating real opportunities for offenders to give back to their community by building and refurbishing items for local groups and organisations, whilst developing transferable skills which could lead to more positive activities on completion of their order. In 16/17 we enabled the completion of 10,515 unpaid work hours and feedback includes "I have learnt skills I didn't think were possible"; - we also promote volunteering both internally and externally, and provide diverse volunteering opportunities within Rainbow Services, including intergenerational, reception, workshop, health programmes, and within communications. These opportunities have been used as springboards to paid employment for many of our volunteers, and for others who require supportive environments we have been able to facilitate learning and development through volunteering. In 16/17 2,984 volunteer hours were completed via Rainbow Services; - we pilot and test new ideas with partners. In previous years this has included a Health Navigation Project, which led to the subsequent development of Care Navigation in West Essex. Currently we are working with groups of VCSE organisations, local and district authority representatives, education providers, and community members to find solutions to youth mental health and youth inactivity in Harlow. In addition to this, in November and December 2017 we worked with Passmores Academy in a test programme they were running to tackle disengagement in education. They released 8 young people in Year 8 who were regularly being sent to the STEP (Students Towards Excellent Progress) team office into community activities, supported by the Alternative Provision Officer (Jo Busson). They tried several different activities, including intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow Services. It was found that the most successful elements of the programme were the intergenerational volunteering with Rainbow, where 2 young boys have continued to volunteer and 1 is considering it, and visits from ex-offenders to discuss their experiences. The young people were also better behaved and focused when doing practical activities which kept them busy. This has led to the development of this Workshop programme, which Passmores is supporting and which has been presented to the Safer Harlow Partnership, members of which have also approved the project and offered support.
recipientOrganization.name: Rainbow Services

recipientOrganization.name: Maze Cares
recipientOrganization.description: Maze Cares provides a welcoming and friendly environment for parent and carers of children with special needs to meet for social interaction, friendship, support, and advice. Through the MAZE Course, which runs for 12 weeks, taking up to 30 parents per course, we help parents better understand and meet the needs of their children. In addition, we offer other support services including monthly coffee mornings, events, speakers, activities, and workshops. Additionally, Maze Cares collaborates with other organisations, voluntary and community sector partners, acting as a signpost to other relevant support, advice and advocacy services. The MAZE Course is a unique approach which aims to develop parent’s knowledge and skills to positively parent their children with disabilities/additional need, such as learning difficulty, autism, ADHD and many other additional needs (SEN/AEN). This work aims to improve family relationships, build social networks of parents and reduce social isolation. The MAZE also aims to empower parents to work towards improving educational outcomes, leisure, and community access opportunities and improving life chances for their children with additional needs. Our funding proposal is for the 12 months from September 2017 to September 2018. Our service users are the parents and carers of children with additional needs. This may be a learning difficulty, physical disability, autism, ADHD, cerebral palsy or any other additional or special need. We have worked with parents of children with a wide range of difficulties. Many parents do not have sufficient knowledge about their child's condition and are not provided with this information on diagnosis. They are often socially isolated because of their child's difficulties, which commonly include challenging behaviour and they also struggle to access appropriate activities out of school hours. These families experience further difficulties with accessing the appropriate education and support for their child, which can result in school exclusions or tribunals. Additionally, the families face difficulties in accessing services such as O/T, speech therapy or short breaks/services through Social Care and also face very restricted leisure opportunities. When parents better understand the additional needs their child has, they are better equipped to raise them. This increased understanding leads to happier parents, happier children and happier siblings, who enjoy a calmer more stable home life, and as a result experience better physical and mental well-being. This is consistently reflected in the feedback we gather at the end of each course. We also hear from parents that after the course they feel empowered by the information and knowledge they have gained. Here’s what our parents have to say about it: “My life changed. I was lost and I didn’t know what to do. After Maze I have the tools that I need to help myself and my child. My child is happier. Less arguments in my household. Siblings are happy and not fighting.” “My son has noticed positive changes to his and my relationship as a result of alterations to our lifestyle…I’ve learned so many positive strategies from Sue and other guests and attendees to use at home, and feel very supported.” “[I have] a better understanding of how my daughter thinks, giving me methods to deal with challenging situations…we’re a lot happier.” “It helped me understand my daughter more… I see people I can relate with and felt I am not alone. This session is making me strong….best course I have ever done for my daughter and myself.” “I feel better able to communicate with my child confidently.” We have a hundreds of feedback forms filled with comments like this and 99.6% of parents highly recommend the MAZE. Benefits generated by the Maze Approach include: * Improved family relationships. * Calmer households and families. * Improved understanding and use of positive strategies * Reduced social isolation as our attendees establish a peer support network. * Improved educational provision as parents & carers are more able to advocate for their child, and work with education professionals to ensure their needs are met. * More positive engagement between professionals (including healthcare) and parents. * Improved educational outcomes – better attendance and reduction in exclusions. * Reduced reliance on mental health services for both parents and children – we have consistent feedback from parents that they feel stronger, more resilient and better supported * Access to ongoing support for an unlimited amount of time and access to this ensures constant progress and stability for our families. To create a sustainable funding model, we would like to trial a year of requesting parental contributions, and analyse: * how many parents are able to make the contribution. * what impact this model has on the number of places requested. * what impact this model has on the % of sessions attended by parents. In order to run this trial we first need: * To create efficient and sustainable administrative systems to cope with the volume of referrals we are handling (pediatricians, EWMHS, Barnardos and other local family support workers refer to us). To date we have supported 3000 families). * To create systems to measure the social impact and outcomes for families, not just over the 12-week duration of the course but in the months following. * To create systems that enable us to manage data responsibly. And, as we are unsure of how much income will be generated, we need to have the basic venue, refreshment and materials costs covered for the two core Colchester programs that we offer. Any revenue generated from the parental contribution would be used to fund a third Colchester program to help reduce our waiting lists.

recipientOrganization.description: The Haven Project supports the recovery of people who have the diagnosis of Personality Disorder. This is a diagnosis which attracts stigma and has traditionally led to a degree of exclusion from many statutory and voluntary mental health services. The people with the diagnosis are overwhelmingly (86%) victims of early childhood abuse and/or neglect and the dysfunctional behaviour and mental torment suffered is in large measure due to this condition. Most individuals also find it very hard to form healthy attachments and this can lead to vey complex and damaging relationships. The Haven Project services are specifically designed- with the clients who have the diagnosis- to maximise recovery, reduce distress and encourage social contribution. It is a psycho-social model which supports awareness and psychological healing whilst at the same time offering clients the opportunity to explore their new found skills in the safe context of the Haven's social networking and friendship groups. The are three main activities: 1) Recovery Groups where clients discuss life skills and emotional resilience, wellbeing, and skills and crafts. 2) Therapeutic Support where clients are able to explore their problems and feelings on a 1:1 basis with qualified staff. 3) Crisis Prevention which is delivered through telephone calls 1:1 face-to-face contact and if needs be outreach ( where clients are visited in their own homes ); clients can also email round the clock or leave telephone messages. In this way the Haven sustains clients in all aspects of their journey towards optimal recovery and a healthy life which enable social inclusion and contribution.

recipientOrganization.name: Your Living Room CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Your Living Room CIC was set up in March 2015 and is currently the only person-centred decluttering service In Essex for people with a hoarding disorder or chronic disorganisation. One in twenty people in the UK are affected by a condition which leads to social isolation, depression, mental ill health and inadequate living conditions. Since 2013 hoarding has been recognised as a mental health disorder in its own right and covered by the Care Act. Harlow, Colchester and Basildon generate over 50% of our referrals which follows the pattern of Index of Multiple Depravation 2010. Our 'pilot' project evidenced that at its most extreme, this problem can be a matter of life and death. We have helped over 95% of clients reclaim their homes with 5% going into care or with family, by using the multi-agency approach as set down by the EST Guidance protocol, following the solution focused approach. Our organisation has seen a 500% increase in referrals in the last 12 months, as demand is now so urgent. Training our staff to a specialist level allows us to address the very complex situations, support clients mental health, well-being and extend our aftercare support plan with an aim to reduce the likelihood of relapse. Over 85% of clients are trapped in isolation and despair without the courage or knowledge of how to take the next step as their impaired health reduces the client’s ability to deal with their escalating situation as Hoarding Disorder creates severe anxiety, increased depression and total isolation, making them a prisoner of their home and their mind. Re-designing our website in June 2016 has seen a 650% increase in traffic and has increased self referral due to its user friendly layout and information. Your Living Room's non-directive solution focused approach asks our clients as part of their assessment, what is their ‘vision’ of a good life? We then work with them at a manageable pace to achieve this goal. 95% of our clients experience mental health problems, therefore we felt it was vital to invite a mental health professional to sit on our board of directors. James Mcquiggan the CEO of Mid and North Essex Mind joined us in March 2017 as a non-executive director. James bring's a wealth of expertise to our new partnership and beneficial for the future development of our services surrounding the mental health welfare of our clients. There is evidence that people that are diagnosed with a serious hoarding disorder and have been though an enforced decluttering process are at a higher risk and over 68% become suicidal. Our person-centred approach reduces the risk significantly and gains the trust of our client and working together to maintain a consistent non-threatening relationship with an agreed mutual goal. Our service is specifically aimed at any person in need, those on lower income and who are in desperate e.g. pending an eviction order. We provide support with applications for funds for clients that are not eligible via statutory services, approx. 70% to enable their decluttering process. Mel Hammond, Operations Director from CAB Tending, Welfare Benefit specialist joined us in September 2016 as a NED and brings specialist knowledge with regards to support around financial capability for our clients. Our wrap-around bespoke ‘aftercare plan’ has been created as a preventative measure to support the client and reduces the risk of re-occurrence beyond the decluttering process: Our clients assessed needs are the basis of their continued pathway out of their suffering and to aid their recovery and improve their health and mental well-being, beyond the remit of statutory services by providing a specialist service to compliment the statutory services provision already in situ. . Following the decluttering process, our non-prescriptive ‘support plan’ offers a selection of options but is not exhaustive of: Holistic therapies to reduce anxiety, person-centred counselling to increase emotional resilience and assistive technology aids that will reduce social isolation and help reintegrate our client and their community back into society and make a lasting difference to their lives. John Mills our third NED, is a Training and Compliance Director for a national organisation. He also audits via the care quality commission standards within private nursing and residential homes. He delivers specialist healthcare training across England. John will ensure we maintain our support within the required boundaries involving the additional therapies and person-centred counselling we are able to offer. Your Living Room's recruitment process is directed to people that are compassionate, provide semi-therapeutic support whilst showing respect and dignity to our clients to ensure that Your Living Room maintains a standard of excellence. The role is rewarding to those that are equipped with the emotional intelligence to handle interpersonal relationships judiciously and empathetically. We provide a focused training programme enabling our practitioners to be competent in providing our clients support, someone to listen and as mediation in relation to family issues or neighbour disputes. Our service provides a safer accessible home environment, thus allowing: social care the ability to implement their ‘care package’ , expedite client discharge from hospital, or provide a safe environment to complete necessary maintenance to the property to meet safety regulations. We look to be a catalyst for change by identifying the clients many ‘triggers points’ and offer a variety of bespoke methodologies and with added support services from Mind addressing our clients needs, help them achieve their goal and enable their independence. Monitoring the overall impact of our person-centred support, reviewing clients case studies, acquired evidence from multi-agency intervention progressively, will produce evidence for innovative approaches to hoarding disorder . Increasing awareness through evidence based data analysis, to share with professionals throughout Essex through the development and delivery of our bespoke accredited training programme, will provide credible evidence to underpin our future development. Our focus will also to make a positive impact within the local economy regarding increased employment opportunities in Essex made available via our new accredited qualification and new health & social care career pathway which will form part of our recruitment development programme for the county.
