recipientOrganization.description: Beacon House provides primary healthcare and wellbeing services to people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness in Colchester and Essex. Our aim is to relieve sickness and poverty for homeless people. Over the 20 years of operation, the primary care services have been added to and adapted to respond to the changing social, economic and political changes that affect homeless people. The majority of our service users have a complex range of support needs relating to their poor mental and physical health, substance misuse issues, poor emotional management and low self-esteem and motivation. They have little or very limited incomes and are supported by dysfunctional family and social networks. These circumstances and life chances can lead to offending behaviours and a cycle of times on the street and times in prison. Their offence history becomes another barrier as they try to rebuild their lives. All of this is compounded by a lack of a safe and stable base or even an address which is necessary to claim benefits, access health services or open a bank account. A case study from "Reducing re-offending by ex-prisoners". Summary of the Social Exclusion Unit report gives a typical example of the homeless and prison cycle: Annette lost her accommodation as a result of entering prison. No one had talked to her when she arrived or during the following months about how she could keep her house or what she could do to ensure that she had somewhere to live on release. Annette’s rent arrears continued to grow while she was in prison and she was evicted. Her early release under curfew was rejected because of the absence of an approved address. On release, her local authority refused to re-house her because of her previous rent arrears. At our day centre in Colchester we are open for at least four hours each day and we do all that we can to address the range of needs of our service users. We have a person-centred approach, and form relationships of trust with people to help them access the external support they need and to identify the internal resilience that they have. We recognise the differing aspects of homelessness including rough sleeping, sofa surfing, hostel places and temporary accommodation, and that these different statuses require different support. We also support people who have been recently housed to encourage the development of social, financial and basic living skills so that they do not lose their tenancies, or return to offending behaviours. We provide services to people at all stages of homelessness. We provide a nurse-led clinic with primary treatment and triage support. The clinic offers a Needle Exchange, Sexual Health testing, protection and advice. We provide screening services and can be the first point of detection for serious health conditions. 70% of people seeing the nurse do not need any further referral to a GP. We provide a barber, a podiatrist, showering facilities and a laundry service to ensure that people are clean and not refused services due to their appearance. We provide new and recycled clothes, bedding and toiletries. We provide a postal address, a place to recharge phones, and a suite of computers for internet access. There are welcoming places where people can get refreshments and hot food. When basic needs are met, we work with individuals to change their circumstances and behaviours, to reduce offending behaviours and dependence on substances, to improve their mental health and their coping mechanisms, to improve their meaningful use of time and their social networks, to improve their personal hygiene and their life skills. We work with each individual on personalized set of goals, which are based on their timescale and are meaningful to them. We host several different voluntary and statutory support services in our building to ensure that there is continuity of care and they are in a safe and supported space. Our occupational therapy support includes art therapy, photography projects, gardening and ecotherapy, and shared cooking and eating. We identify some of the behaviours that are trauma related, and work with people to develop alternative strategies to manage their pain, rejection and hopelessness. A considerable part of our support function is to work with housing providers, employers and other support agencies. We are often the only organisation who has had consistent and on-going interaction with some of the most marginalized people in Colchester. We are therefore able to provide references for landlords and employers. We often prepare character references for people attending magistrates court, and often represent individuals at joint agency case conferences. Our unique position of supporting people before they are ready to engage with services makes us invaluable at the point where they want to change, but only have a bad record for their past behaviours. We act as arbitrators for landlords, and have established relationships with landlords where no deposit is required if the tenant is referred by Beacon House. Many of the costs of re-offending by ex-prisoners are not quantifiable, but can be devastating and longterm, and are frequently felt by the most vulnerable in society. Most obviously, there is the impact on victims, many of whom will be repeat victims, and on their families; also on communities, predominantly the most disadvantaged. In turn, where re-offenders are caught and imprisoned, a heavy toll is taken on their families and on their own lives. It is difficult to assess at which point an individual will decide to change their own mindset and behaviours that will enable them to face their daily challenges without resorting to substances or offending behaviour. We have created an environment at Beacon House where people feel accepted, supported and able to accept support and help to move forward towards acceptance and stability in the wider community.

recipientOrganization.description: Saha is a charitable provider of social housing and support services across England. The Association is registered under the Co-operative and Community Benefit Societies Act 2014 (registration no. 15210R) and the Homes and Communities Agency (registration no. LH 2429). Saha provides accommodation for a range of different people, young and old. Our support services help people to develop their personal talents, flourish and live independently. Our principal activities are the development and management of social housing, primarily for single people. This includes Lifehouses for homeless people, Foyers offering support and training and housing with appropriate support services for vulnerable people. Braintree Foyer is managed and owned by the Salvation Army Housing Association. The Foyer provides accommodation, support and training for 35 people aged 18 – 35 who have experienced homelessness. Braintree Foyer was officially opened in November 1994 as the first purpose built foyer in the UK. Since it opened the foyer has provided accommodation, support and training for over 1000 young people from the Braintree District. In recent years the foyer has been increasingly recognised as an exceptional service and was only the second service ever to receive the Foyer Federation Transformational Innovation Award. In 2016 Braintree Foyer was a finalist of the Essex ‘Who Will Care’ Innovation Award. Over the past 6 years the Foyer has had an 86% success rate of young people making a positive move on from the foyer. The foyer is always fully occupied and has a waiting list. Braintree Foyer regularly receives visits from international organisations who want to learn about the foyer service. At the last service review undertaken by Essex County Council, Braintree Foyer was commended as, ‘showing how innovative and creative ideas can support young people to reach goals. The service has a ‘can do’ attitude and approach and is very warm and welcoming to both service users and the wider community. The staff are engaged and committed to the work they do with their young people and encourage individual learning with an aim to develop independent living skills. Management are focused and open to experiment with new innovative ideas that can assist in developing the above. The service shares good practice with other partners and has an open door policy to share the services good practice’. Braintree Foyer residents come to us from very chaotic backgrounds, having suffered abuse, family breakdown or substance misuse and have been sleeping rough or sofa surfing. Our residents also include care leavers, young people with learning difficulties and mental health issues; they are vulnerable young adults with low self-esteem who find it hard to see a positive future. Many take prescription anti-depressants and self-harming is common. However Braintree Foyer is a service which sees the potential in all young people and which focuses on the person rather than the problem. We challenge young people to be the best that they possibly can by nurturing and promoting young people’s talents and aspirations. Braintree Foyer also supports many young people from the local community through its project work including: Braintree Discovery College Braintree Discovery College was launched in April 2015 to provide a broad curriculum of free courses with the aim of reigniting a love of learning in people who have experienced disadvantage in their lives. Braintree Discovery College removes the barriers to learning and empowers young people take control of their own personal development. Braintree Discovery College offers courses which are completely on the learners own terms and as a result it has been very successful in engaging hard to reach young people. Courses are delivered by volunteers from the local community and further afield. We have high calibre volunteer tutors at the Discovery College including academics, CEO's, authors, campaigners and people who will inspire our young people such as the Paralympian Anne Wafula Strike and the former world champion natural bodybuilder Alun Davies. Since the launch in 2015 over 400 young people have enrolled as students of Braintree Discovery College and more than 1200 sessions have been delivered. Braintree Foyer Community Gym Braintree Foyer Community Gym was opened in 2010 to offer a fully equipped free gym for young people who live at the foyer and people from our local community. Since then more than 300 people have used the gym and completed gym inductions and personal training plans with our gym instructors. At any one time there are 70+ regular active users of the gym. In addition to personal training the Gym offers fitness boot camps, circuit training and the 'Ladies that Lift' Programme which encourages young women to use weight training as part of their excercise. The people from the local community who use our gym are people who would be unable to afford gym memberships at commercial gyms. The Foyer is committed to improving the health and wellbeing of young people. Braintree Sound Academy Braintree Sound Academy was established in 2012 to offer free music workshops and live gigs for young people from Braintree District. The project offers workshops 3 evenings per week and intensive week long courses during the school holidays. Workshops include guitar lessons, drum lessons, singing, sound recording, sound engineering, song writing and DJ and MC workshops At the end of each course is a live gig and since 2012 more than 10,000 people have seen young people from Braintree Sound Academy perform at music festivals, Bocking Arts Theatre and even the Royal Opera House.

grants.description: The project aims to provide support for women affected by DV/SV and prevent its escalation through individually tailored advice, support and therapeutic services to enable women to cope, recover and move to independence.   We will provide four key service areas with a holistic delivery model providing initial response to VAWG as well as after care from IDVA services: - Advice, including legal support, through a hub and spoke model and inclusive of targeted support for BME women, those with NRPF and young and sexually exploited women as well as women with problematic substance use. We will provide a specialist focus on housing support with a dedicated housing support officer and access to safe accommodation.  - One to one BACP accredited counselling delivered within each borough as well as counselling in over 20 languages provided by BME led by and for organisations.    - Group work in all Boroughs and BME partner organisations to aid recovery and increase understanding of abuse.  - Training including legal training to professionals and accredited VAWG training to volunteers and therapeutic training to clinicians.   We will deliver a range of outcomes including increased safety, access to safe housing, legal support, reduced risk, improved mental/physical health and well-being, increased confidence/self-esteem and increased knowledge for service providers around DV/SV.

recipientOrganization.description: The Clockhouse Project has been operational in the Leys since 2007 and aims to relieve poverty, reduce loneliness and isolation and transform people’s lives. We have worked with many local organisations, done considerable outreach and consultations with local older people. Both our current programme and future plans directly reflect older users' priorities. Over the past year, the Clockhouse Project has run joint activities with 10 different partner organisations (including Oxfordshire Adult Learning, Agnes Smith Advice Centre, Oxford Brookes University, housing associations, African School etc). Our strong "grass-roots" base combined with an excellent range of partnerships means we can act quickly and imaginatively to respond to new opportunities which tie in with our users’ priorities. Recent examples include community mosaic project with Oxford WEA which proved very popular with local over-50's and Time to Talk, a project which created short films with individual residents that formed part of a reminiscence exhibition at the Museum of Oxford. Outreach work is vital. Our worker knows how difficult it is for isolated people to pluck up the courage to 'leave the house; some need many hours' support, plus regular transport help, to take this step successfully. Personal contact and care makes the project successful.

grants.description: Where does the OCD end and where do I begin? Research and Development of Head Hand Head (Part II), a new performance, using myself as subject, based on personal experience of living with obsessive compulsive disorder and receiving cognitive behavioural therapy as treatment. Working with Professor Trevor Robbins and his team of neuroscientists at Cambridge University, together with artistic collaborators, Chris Goode, Daisy Orton and Cathy Westbrook and a cognitive behavioural therapist from Maud sley Hospital, the project will couple emotional responses with scientific and psychological theories and research currently being developed within the field of neuroscience to create an intimate, participatory, theatrical space within which the audience will be inspired to reflect upon and reconsider their individual, cultural and political attitudes towards representations and realities of mental illness, and its treatment. This project will include a number of work in progress and pilot perfo rmances to test the work within different contexts, for theatre audiences and for clinicians, service users and academics within the health sector. This will lead to the creation of a final performance, Head Hand Head (Part II) which will be ready to tour. It will be able to be presented as a stand alone show or together with Head Hand Head (Part I), an intimate solo performance created in 2013 for small audiences and premiered at Edinburgh Fringe Festival, drawing on my own experiences of livin g with OCD, from the perspective of pre-diagnosis and pre-treatment.

grants.description:
The Reading Agency have recently extended their 'Books on Prescription' scheme, launching a new 'Shelf Help' reading scheme for young people who come in to contact with mental health issues. The aim is to help these young people to better understand and deal with their situation. We aim to explore the impact of 'Shelf-Help' on users within a school setting and to further understand how young people prefer to engage with this scheme.
We will undertake interviews and focus groups with school pupils and key stakeholders of the scheme to gather key information:

What are peoples’ baseline reading practices?
How were the books used/engaged with?
Have the books changed peoples’ perceptions?
Did the books help people and how?
Have people made changes as a result of reading the book(s)?
Were there any negatives?
Are there areas that weren’t covered on the list that people think would be good to include?

This work will go towards producing a theory of change framework which can be used to underpin future research in the area, identifying suitable outcomes that could be measured to evaluate the scheme. It will also provide practical information about the scheme's implementation, so that it can be continually improved.

recipientOrganization.name: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

grants.description: Mental, neurological and substance use (MNS) disorders are a leading, but neglected, cause of morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa [1]. MNS disorders account for >25% of all years lived with disability globally, more than cardiac disease or cancer [2]. The treatment gap is vast, only 10% of people with MNS disorders in low-income countries access evidence-based treatments, compared to 33% in high-income countries [3]. Reasons for this include low awareness ofthe burden of MNS disorders and limited evidence to support development, adaptation and implementation of effective and feasible treatments. While pockets of mental health research excellence exist in Africa, MNS research capacity is generally limited, particularly in mental health intervention, service and system research. Mental health research excellence is currently undermined by restricted opportunities for training and mentorship, unclear career pathways, lack of integration in general medical settings, limited multi-disciplinary collaboration and the lack of a critical mass of MNS researchers and leaders. The overall goals of the African Mental Health Research Initiative (AMARI) areto build an African-led network of MNS researchers in Ethiopia, Malawi, South Africa and Zimbabwe, equipped to lead high quality mental health research programmes that meet the needs of their countries, and to establish a sustainable career pipeline for these researchers with the emphasis on integrating MNS research into existing programmes such as HIV/AIDS, maternal and child health. The objectives are to: 1. Select and train MNS research fellows from a range of disciplines at masters (n=25), PhD (n=20) and post-doctoral (n=6) levels in research excellence; 2. Build leadership skills of 26 fellows through adaptation of KCL Career Development Series on Leadership, Management and Mentoring; 3. Design and test an advocacy and systems change strategy for each country, aimed at building sustainable career pathways in MNS academia; 4. Develop a web-based support platform for training, supervision and networking. In year 1 we will undertake preparatory work to inform course development, thedesign of the advocacy and systems change strategy and gather baseline data for each country, for evaluation purposes, conducting qualitative and quantitative interviews with local policymakers and service users to identify needs and priorities through a theory of change map. We willtrain local supervisors, run pre-application workshops for potential applicants and assess existing training materials. . In years 2-5, fellows will begin higher degrees and courses as relevant. Trainingwill be mostly in Africa and using a) joint supervision by local and external supervisors with multidisciplinary expertise, b) taught modules in advanced MNS research methods, writing, and engagement with policy makers, and c) undertaking high priority MNS research. The underlying ethos of AMARI will be to ensure LMIC partner capacity is strengthened progressively towards self-sufficiency to ensure sustainability longer term. AMARI will be led by University of Zimbabwe College of Health Sciences (UZ-CHS). All consortium institutions will provide course facilitators and supervisors, with the Centrefor Global Mental Health (CGMH), University of Cape Town (UCT) and University College London (UCL) providing external supervision, research experts and materials for adaptation.

grants.description: Artful Experts Season is a pilot public engagement programme of exhibitions, music, events and live performances by people with lived experience of mental distress. Curated by arts and mental health charity DLL, the programme will bring together expert collaborators from the fields of mental health, digital media and the arts to explore methods of public engagement, with a view to a larger scale World Mental Health Day 2015 programme. Our Steering Group, Advisory Panel and Creative Collaborato r team will work with an external Evaluator to direct and shape public engagement, evaluative and data gathering methodology; test and critique processes during the programme; and develop material into assets that can inform future public engagement methodology. A two-minute film and formal Evaluation document will be publically shared. Public engagement will be driven by accessible exhibitions and live shows, social media and web activity, including an online animated serial narrated by comic  character Dr Bobby. The vibrant programme will culminate in the Artful Symposium. This unusual artist-led event at the Royal Society of Medicine will present invited mental health audiences with art and performances by people with personal experience of mental illness. The aim is that this unique context of a shared mediating experience of art will form the basis for reflection and fresh dialogue around mental health in this historically fraught and polarised field. DLL believes that art can off er a transformative basis for public engagement with mental health, where experts by experience work together with experts by profession.

recipientOrganization.name: Stepping Out Theatre
recipientOrganization.description: Stepping Out Theatre is a registered charity and the UK’s leading mental health theatre company. With 58 production credits to our name, we work with over 100 mental health service users every year, using performing arts as an instrument for recovery, personal development and social change. Our aims are: 1) To relieve the conditions of mental health service users through the medium of theatre. 2) To advance the education of the public about mental health in order to raise their awareness, by producing plays which deal with this issue and counter negative stereotypes of people with mental health problems. 3) To advance the education and training of mental health service users and their allies to develop their creative talents, build supportive networks and produce high quality theatre on mental health themes. We deliver a range of programmes including workshops, mentoring, educational opportunities, social trips and a holistic package of support including housing, benefits, career progression and emotional welfare. We have an excellent track record involving service users in range of work from large scale community theatre productions to high quality professional performances on mental health themes giving them a voice and a platform to bring compelling stories alive on stage.

grants.description: A growing number of people use the net to find information on medical problems, to chat in online health forums, and even self-diagnose and self-medicate.  This has created new, very large data sets of unregulated user-generated health data. This study will explore whether this data can be exploited to: 1) spot trends in citizen-generated unregulated health data online, using a pilot study drawn from mental health.  2) provide useable and robust insight for health professionals and clini cians that will in turn enable them to: a. Quickly spot emerging trends b. Provide early warning signs where there might be a lack of official provision, and use online data to inform a response c. Better understand public and patient attitudes and feedback towards certain types of prescription and treatment d. Understand the risks and opportunities to patients of these source of information e. Understand the potential uses of this information by clinicians and health services f. Exami ne the ethical, regulatory and legal implications 3) demonstrate the potential for further and wider application of these methods within mental health, and beyond.

grants.Other Applicant(s): Dr Katherine Sorsdahl, Dr Melanie Abas, Dr Charlotte Hanlon, Dr Felix Kauye, Prof Frances Cowan, Prof Crick Lund, Ricardo Araya
grants.description: Mental, neurological and substance use (MNS) disorders are a leading, but neglected, cause of morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa [1]. MNS disorders account for >25% of all years lived with disability globally, more than cardiac disease or cancer [2]. The treatment gap is vast, only 10% of people with MNS disorders in low-income countries access evidence-based treatments, compared to 33% in high-income countries [3]. Reasons for this include low awareness ofthe burden of MNS disorders and limited evidence to support development, adaptation and implementation of effective and feasible treatments. While pockets of mental health research excellence exist in Africa, MNS research capacity is generally limited, particularly in mental health intervention, service and system research. Mental health research excellence is currently undermined by restricted opportunities for training and mentorship, unclear career pathways, lack of integration in general medical settings, limited multi-disciplinary collaboration and the lack of a critical mass of MNS researchers and leaders. The overall goals of the African Mental Health Research Initiative (AMARI) areto build an African-led network of MNS researchers in Ethiopia, Malawi, South Africa and Zimbabwe, equipped to lead high quality mental health research programmes that meet the needs of their countries, and to establish a sustainable career pipeline for these researchers with the emphasis on integrating MNS research into existing programmes such as HIV/AIDS, maternal and child health. The objectives are to: 1. Select and train MNS research fellows from a range of disciplines at masters (n=25), PhD (n=20) and post-doctoral (n=6) levels in research excellence; 2. Build leadership skills of 26 fellows through adaptation of KCL Career Development Series on Leadership, Management and Mentoring; 3. Design and test an advocacy and systems change strategy for each country, aimed at building sustainable career pathways in MNS academia; 4. Develop a web-based support platform for training, supervision and networking. In year 1 we will undertake preparatory work to inform course development, thedesign of the advocacy and systems change strategy and gather baseline data for each country, for evaluation purposes, conducting qualitative and quantitative interviews with local policymakers and service users to identify needs and priorities through a theory of change map. We willtrain local supervisors, run pre-application workshops for potential applicants and assess existing training materials. . In years 2-5, fellows will begin higher degrees and courses as relevant. Trainingwill be mostly in Africa and using a) joint supervision by local and external supervisors with multidisciplinary expertise, b) taught modules in advanced MNS research methods, writing, and engagement with policy makers, and c) undertaking high priority MNS research. The underlying ethos of AMARI will be to ensure LMIC partner capacity is strengthened progressively towards self-sufficiency to ensure sustainability longer term. AMARI will be led by University of Zimbabwe College of Health Sciences (UZ-CHS). All consortium institutions will provide course facilitators and supervisors, with the Centrefor Global Mental Health (CGMH), University of Cape Town (UCT) and University College London (UCL) providing external supervision, research experts and materials for adaptation.

grants.description: The project will bring together for the first time the historical and conteporary strands that make up the field of user-led research in mental health. This field destabilises the knowledge base of mental health discourse and practice, where experts have hitherto been seen as the custodians of evidence and knowledge. Positioned as ‘unreason’ since the Enlightenment, it may seem a contradiction that ‘mad’ people could enter the spaces of the academy and generate credible knowledge. To let service users speak in this way promises a novel if troubling project, and one that may prove an antidote to common understandings, professional and lay. The project will trace the histories of mental health user movements internationally as well as those of user-led research, which was grounded in these movements.  The different strands currently making up user-led research will be interrogated as to whether they form a coherent discourse. Interviews and document analysis will be used to understand these questions and the analysis will be guided by adaptations of contemporary theories of resistance and critical theory. Finally, the impacts of user-led research on mental health services provision will be investigated, both what has been achieved and what is envisioned.

grants.description: My investigations to date have focussed on a simple rule switching task in which the association between a symbolic visual cue and the direction of a saccadic eye movement can change from trial to trial. This has led me to propose a model of adaptive behavioural control in which perceptual input can initiate behaviour via two parallel routes. An associative  system is proposed subject to affective  feedback, with positively valued outcomes leading to strengthening of stimulus-response connecti ons and negative outcomes leading to weakening of these linkages. In contrast a Rule  based system represents associations supramodally and exerts indirect control of behaviour via the associative system. Updating of current rules occurs following breaches in outcome expectancy. During my sabbatical I will carry out a meta-analysis of the functional imaging literature to determine to what extent the discrete feedback systems proposed for the associative and rule based systems are anatomically s egregated. I will also develop new oculomotor tasks that probe the functions of the associative system in order to reveal dissociations between the rule based system and deficits in associative learning processes in neurologically damaged patients.

recipientOrganization.description: Established by local people in 1986, the farm has grown into a popular, valued and respected community managed project that forms part of the local community, providing services and opportunities that extend well beyond community farming and gardening. We are often described as a community centre without a roof! The farm remains firmly focused on enabling people and communities to grow. In response to the needs of local residents, many of who experience high levels of deprivation and disadvantage, we provide a range of innovative and inspiring educational, environmental and recreational activities that facilitate personal development, promote health and wellbeing, social cohesion and community regeneration. Our work particularly benefits disadvantaged local young people, young families, disabled people, isolated older people and people experiencing mental health problems. Our success at engaging the local community and hard-to-reach people has led to Bristol City Council regarding our project as a major player in the future community development of the area.

recipientOrganization.description: Southside aims to ensure that children, young people and adults with multiple and complex difficulties in Bath and North East Somerset access the care and support they need, so their families enjoy the safety, experiences and opportunities they deserve. Southside works with people whose lives have been damaged by violence, abuse and neglect. More than two thirds of those we support have been victims of domestic abuse, causing emotional and mental ill-health, social isolation, homelessness and debt. We provide attachment-based whole family support to meet needs of the children, young people and adults involving: • assessment, multi-agency planning, packages of support which include home-based, therapeutically focused parenting support • domestic violence advice and advocacy for parents • specialist support for young victims • young people led volunteering and advocacy (Young Advocates) • counselling • peer support within community hub groups with children’s play • therapeutic play for children • help to access services to tackle debt, substance abuse, mental health, physical well-being, social support • help to access education and training For over twenty years, Southside has been ‘standing behind’ people when they need us, in a non-judgemental, compassionate and encouraging way. We have deep roots in local communities and are known and trusted.

recipientOrganization.description: Our aims and objectives are to help older people who are lonely and suffering from social and community isolation. We create a family environment and refer to our service users as “Friends”. On a weekly basis we provide a range of social and therapeutic activities for 120 older people (aged 50 -100+) whose financial, physical and mental well-being are affected by the impact of loneliness. The weekly events take place: • Monday 7.30p.m. – 8.45p.m. • Wednesday 10.30a.m. – 12.00noon. • Friday 7.30p.m. – 9.00p.m The distinctive nature of Archway’s social groups is the emphasis on high levels of support and encouragement, with every effort made to ensure an individual receives what they need to enable them to take the step of coming along to the social group on a consistent basis. For those who struggle to engage in activities we provide them with a buddy who provides a listening ear, models good social communication, facilitates interaction in a small supportive group and encourages participation at a level each individual is comfortable with. For those unable to access our evening social groups independently through physical or emotional challenges we provide a volunteer transport service. We provide a home visiting befriending service for 52 older people who are too frail or lack the confidence to access our weekly social and therapeutic activities. Below is a quote from one of our Befrienders’ “I am very grateful that she comes to see me. It does cheer me up. I look forward to visits and seeing someone different.” Where funding allows we also hold Special celebration events (Christmas, New Year, Bonfire Night). We also provide a wide range of volunteering opportunities for our Friends and members of the wider community.
recipientOrganization.name: Archway Foundation

grants.description: Befriending Service Increasing CapacityThrough a variety of carefully organised activities, we support and befriend those experiencing loneliness and isolation; • providing a sense of belonging for those who feel unwanted, excluded and forgotten • offering the opportunity to make friends and meet people in a supportive environment • helping people to regain social confidence and contribute to society Direct benefit: Those in receipt of our service benefiting from a reduction in loneliness, improved social confidence, wider network of social contacts. Indirect Beneficiaries: Families are often relieved to know there is someone providing support and companionship to their loved one. Given the known links between loneliness and mental and physical ill health, our services helps to improve health and well-being of individuals with a knock on effect of reduced demand on health & social care services. We rely heavily on volunteer input and volunteering reduces loneliness, improves connectedness with local community develops skills and improves confidence. To recruit a Volunteer Recruitment & Training Co-ordinator to be responsible for volunteer recruitment and taking volunteers through the whole recruitment, interviewing, vetting and induction process (reviewing and improving office systems in the process) and increasing our capacity to match volunteers with those waiting for a befriender. The Co-ordinator will work with other staff responsible for managing referrals (typically from health and social services) of those in need of befriending and ensure that the matching of volunteers and referrals is optimised and greatly accelerated. To reduce the befriending waiting list by responding in a timelier manner to those in need of the befriending service and to those expressing an interest in volunteering. This requires an additional resource – a Volunteer Recruitment & Training Co-ordinator. Having one person responsible for volunteer recruitment and processing through to readiness for matching will also enable review and streamlining of our current systems, thereby improving efficiency in the longer term. To reduce the administrative load on existing staff who have stepped in to respond to increased demand on the service but whose workloads are becoming unmanageable and unsustainable.

BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to:
 - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them.
- Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability

BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.

recipientOrganization.description:
Our vision is that people coming to Bristol to seek sanctuary are welcomed and treated with dignity and respect.  

Our mission is to welcome asylum seekers and refugees in Bristol.  Together we create a place of solidarity and trust.  We challenge the injustices that we experience and witness in the UK.  Learning from each other we develop partnerships and links with the wider community to promote equality of opportunity for asylum seekers and refugees.  

Our activities:
We are open 3 days a week with services including: a drop in hub for wellbeing, drinks and snacks, games and activities, hot food; ESOL classes; a pre-school creche/Early Years Project and volunteering for service users.  Activities relevant to this application include:
1.	The Advocacy and Information Desk (AID): support, signposting and referrals to access services, ensure protection of human rights, find ways out of destitution, and get support to make fresh claims and eventually leave to remain.  
2.	The Asylum Support Project (ASP): advice on making applications for asylum support and accommodation and challenging refusals.  
3.	Destitution Support: asylum seekers and refugees who are not receiving financial support can access a food bank, toiletries, clothes and household items.
recipientOrganization.name: Bristol Refugee Rights

grants.description: We run a Welcome Centre for asylum seekers and new refugees in the centre of Bristol 3 days each week over 48 weeks of the year.  The Centre has developed over the course of 10 years with regular input from members (asylum seekers and refugees) who are encouraged to be involved in the running of the organisation from the time they join.  The organisation offers free English classes, computer classes, trips, advocacy and information, support with asylum applications, opportunities to take part in public speaking, to train to be an interpreter; families can use the Early Years project for children under 5, and more.  At the heart of the Centre there is a space for members to meet each other, develop friendships, and obtain emotional and wellbeing support.  They can access: a cooked meal, refreshments, games, arts and crafts, destitution bags, a free haircut, massages, community interpreters, be referred to the Bristol Bike Project, see the asylum nurse, meet with a mental health volunteer from MIND and more.  Additionally the organisation works in partnership with other groups in the city to host an event on Human Rights Day each year and activities and celebrations within National Refugee Week.  Last year at least 850 asylum seekers and new refugees benefited from our Welcome Centre.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services
grants.title: Asylum Seeker and Refugee Well Being Project

recipientOrganization.description: Our Mission To relieve hardship and distress amongst the homeless primarily but not exclusively within the district administered by Essex County Council and amongst those living in adverse housing conditions, in particular but not exclusively by a) the provision of emergency accommodation and associated services, and b) the provision of assistance towards acquiring a settled way of life through rehabilitation and permanent accommodation. Our Values We care for the homeless and vulnerable; respecting their need for safety and dignity. We promote a sense of security, self worth and acceptance of the diversity of the individuals we serve. We encourage the growth and development of our staff and service users through partnerships and training opportunities with others. We are committed to equality of opportunity for all. Our Aims We encourage responsible living standards from our service users. To provide an adequate number of good standard accommodation for the single homeless. Encouraging service users to rejoin society society as useful members. Supporting improvement in the health and well being of service users without discrimination or judgement. Giving practical help in achieving independent living and employment. Raising awareness of homelessness in Chelmsford and Essex. To become a catalyst for change and partnership recognising the resources of others. In order to meet our mission and aims we provide a 7 bedroom direct access night shelter (soon to be a 9 bedroom night shelter when we move to our new premises on New London Road) giving accommodation to people who would otherwise be street homeless. Each resident is allocated a support worker to assist the resident to identify what lead them to become homeless and identify ways to prevent this in the future. Basic counselling is provided but if this grant application is awarded it would allow for more specialist trauma therapy to be provided to improve the chances of the resident succeeding in moving on in a positive way. Five move on properties are provided to allow a stepped process of change towards more independent accommodation outside of CHESS. In total we can house up to 30 individuals at any given time. The night shelter provides meals for residents, washing/hygiene facilities in addition to the accommodation plus volunteer staff who provide a non-judgemental, listening ear for the residents to be accepted as a person. We also provide those who are rough sleeping with hot food and drinks each evening at the night shelter together with sleeping bags if needed to reduce the hardship of sleeping rough. During the Winter months this is extended to operating a Winter project using the safety of a church hall to accommodate a further 10 people in the warm and out of the harsh weather.
recipientOrganization.name: CHESS

recipientOrganization.description: What we do: We provide a user-led vocational rehabilitation service that includes therapeutic work-experience and vocational skills-development for adults recovering from illness and/or suffering social disadvantage. This is conducted in a safe and supportive environment. Our work is conducted on an on-going basis. Clients are referred to us when they are in need of our services. All individuals are different, as are their needs and their rehabilitation requirements. We facilitate recovery at a pace that is suited to each individual. Aims and Objectives: The organisation was set up in 1995, as a company limited by guarantee with charitable aims, to serve the interests of those individuals recovering from long term mental health problems. We now also accept people with other disabilities such as mild learning difficulties or head injuries, but the majority of beneficiaries remain those recovering from mental ill health. Our objectives are; • To work towards improving the social wellbeing and quality of life of our service users; • To provide continuous learning and development opportunities for our beneficiaries; • To provide furniture restoration services to the general public, to partly fund the first two objectives but primarily to facilitate the re-integration of our service users in to main stream society. We aim to make a lasting difference to the lives of our service users who, because of the nature of their disabilities, experience barriers to full participation within the community. . Training, Skills, Qualifications and Work Experience: Training and Qualifications; The Co-operative has been a City & Guilds approved centre since 1997. We offer service users training, in all aspects of furniture restoration, where they have opportunities to work towards gaining City & Guilds Qualifications in the following subjects at level 1 and 2: • French Polishing • Cabinet Making • Upholstery Skills; Clients learn practical skills and underpinning knowledge, as required by the qualification being pursued; they receive support and guidance on a one to one basis from two qualified trainers. We also offer additional training in Business Administration and Book keeping although this is unaccredited. Work Experience; An important aspect of clients’ involvement is for them to gain genuine work experience to enhance their future employment prospects. All service users are engaged in activity that offers a high level of participation and engagement. An aspect of this is clients’ involvement in the delivery of furniture services to the public. This gives them a further opportunity to apply the skills learnt during courses in a work environment and to regain a wider consideration of the responsibilities of being an employee. Working with other organisations; We are regularly contacted by, and work in partnership with, referring agencies including NHS rehabilitation teams, social services and charitable organisations. We work in partnership with support workers from, mainly, community mental health teams and, on occasions, social services and other referring agencies. Individuals receive support and clinical care from these organisations. We offer a service which is not provided by these agencies, but which complements the work they do and seeks to reduce barriers to service users’ recovery and their engagement with society. Alleviating Stigma and Discrimination – and social isolation; Houses of Parliament POST NOTE Number 422, October 2012, addressing Stigma and Discrimination, reports- “Stigma and discrimination are barriers to accessing social environments such as the workplace. They can affect individuals when seeking employment. For example, a survey conducted by the anti-stigma and discrimination campaign, Time to Change, found that of 2,082 people surveyed, 56% would not employ an individual who had depression even if they were the most suitable candidate”. Our furniture services, together with evening classes that are made available to the general public, provide a wider benefit to the local community. We help to raise awareness among our customers - through explaining the social aspect of our work, about the issue of disability and how this presents barriers to participation in the community. This together with clients’ contact with the public helps to alleviate stigma and discrimination and reduce social isolation. Evidence of Need We have provided a valuable and unique service that has operated in Chelmsford for almost 23 years, during which time there has been a waiting list. Millrace has developed a reputation for good practice within the mental health sector in Mid-Essex and helped over 140 people. The service is unique to the area in terms of the environment and skills taught. A strong link exists between social deprivation and poor mental health. There are wards situated in North East Chelmsford where there are higher than average levels of deprivation. “One in six people in the Essex will suffer a mental health problem in the course of this year. Although the numbers are predicted to remain stable, more people whose mental health problems currently go untreated are predicted to come forward as a result of better diagnosis and increased awareness due to Public health campaigns intended to reduce stigma.” (Source: Hope for Better Mental Health, Public Office Essex County Council 2015).

recipientOrganization.description: The stated objectives of Thurrock Mind are: - • To promote mental health and to assist in relieving and rehabilitating persons suffering from mental disorder or conditions of emotional or mental distress requiring advice or treatment. • To promote debate on mental health issues and disseminate information concerning the same and to educate the public in matters relating to mental health. Thurrock Mind exists to promote mental health, to foster and encourage greater understanding of mental health problems; to aid the development of good quality voluntary and statutory mental health services and to represent the concerns and common interests of users of the service, their families and members of the public. Those people who are labelled, treated or diagnosed as mentally ill have the same rights as any other person and should not be disadvantaged or subject to prejudice. Mind recognises the value of people with experience of mental distress and wishes to listen and learn from them. It seeks to foster and enable user consultation and participation in the planning and delivery of mental health service. We provide services for Thurrock adults experiencing emotional and mental distress and our main activities are; Advocacy • Care Act Advocacy - Thurrock Mind in partnership with Thurrock Centre for Independent Living (TCIL) provides a Thurrock-based advocacy service, with local knowledge. We combine advocacy with active support such as help with filling in forms, making phone calls and signposting. The service is for adults from the following client groups: Learning Disability, Mental Health, Sensory Impairment, Acquired Brain Injury, Substantial Difficulty, Dementia, Drug / Alcohol) and their carers. • Independent Mental Health Advocate (IMHA)- This is a service for Thurrock adults who are eligible under Mental Health Act 1983 (Amended 2007) requiring independent specialist mental health advocacy. Cariads – In partnership with TCIL and Thurrock Lifestyle Solutions, we provide information, advice and support to unpaid carers in Thurrock. Day Opportunities • Peoples space – Environment for adults, experiencing mental health problems to meet socially with peers • Personal Assistant service is available to adults, experiencing mental health problems, who are able to purchase support from their Personal Budget or self-fund (£13.50 per hour). A bespoke programme is developed for the individual, with emphasis on developing life skills, social inclusion, building confidence, increasing self-esteem and maintaining wellbeing. Peer Mentoring and Peer Support- The Peer to Peer Support Project is focused on empowerment of individuals through community. It aims to support people who have, or are likely to develop, a mental health problem to stay well. There is Peer Mentoring, which is one to one support between a peer supporter (someone who has lived mental health experience) and a peer (someone who needs support). In this partnership, the emphasis is on identifying and working towards a short term goal to improve wellbeing. The empathy that comes from being a peer supporter allows an environment of trust, so the commitment to staying well is sustained long after the partnership ends. There are also Peer Support Groups, where people come together to do something they enjoy. This could be through joining an interest group, sharing skills with others or getting out into the community. Stepping Stones- Our gardening project provides an opportunity for adults experiencing mental health problems to be involved with a varied range of horticultural activities and engage with the great outdoors. Trainees can work towards vocational goals and/or gain valuable skills in a safe and supportive environment. Therapies • Inclusion Thurrock – In partnership with SSSFT we provide;  Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT); One to one or group therapy or Computerised Cognitive Behavioural therapy (CCBT)  Recovery College- Aims to teach people to manage their mental health by learning from the tutors; one professional and the other an individual with lived experience of mental health problems. • Counselling & Groupwork for individuals or couples, and groupwork courses Anger Management, Confidence, Assertiveness, Depression, Anxiety. • Multi Ethnic Counselling Service for people from the Black and Minority Ethnic community. Volunteering – We have a range of opportunities; Trustee, retail, admin, horticulture, photography etc. World of Work In partnership with TCIL we provide the World of Work programme for people with mental health problems. We provide personalised and tailored support to enable people to become more independent and reach their potential. Individual appointments and a 12 session ‘preparing 4 work’ programme are provided. Thurrock Mind’s quality marks / standards; • ISO 9001 – We met the requirement of ISO 9001 in ‘The management of support for people experiencing emotional and mental distress.’ • Mind Quality Management • Advice Quality Standard (Advocacy & Cariads) • Investors in People-Silver • Investing in Volunteers • Mentoring & Befriending Foundation Approved Provider • British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP) • Thurrock Mind has signed the Charter for Employers who are positive about mental health; Mindful Employer Thurrock’s Shared Care Protocol involves four organisations, of which Thurrock Mind is one of them. Patients from the Community Mental Health Team will be discharged to our Recovery Transfer Facilitator, who in turn will support individuals to access community groups/activities/ services.

recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Essex (HSE) is a leading family support charity based in Essex working to achieve healthy and positive outcomes for children and families. Our work comprises a long-established volunteer home visiting service, offering emotional and practical help to families experiencing difficulties, alongside a range of family groups, well-being programmes, courses and events. What makes our charity special, is that all our trained volunteers have lived experience as parents/carers themselves. We believe in the power of community mobilisation, and so invest in local areas to support local families. Our Vision is: ‘For every child and young person in Essex to grow up in a family that is strong, resilient and able to access the support they need; when and where they need it’ HSE recognises that bringing up children can be hard work. All parents and carers will, from time to time, encounter problems which make the task harder. The key to success is for parents and carers to be strong and resilient, so they can meet challenges head on, and navigate their way through or around them successfully. Through mobilising hundreds of volunteers, we support families to help themselves, developing parenting skills and improving connections in their community. Our volunteers support families struggling with: • Mental Health issues (including peri/post-natal depression, etc.) • Financial hardship • Physical health issues • Single parenthood • Low self-esteem and confidence • Domestic abuse • Isolation • Routines and boundaries • Bereavement and other significant life events The main activities of HSE are as follows: • Home-Visiting service, led by volunteers • Family Groups • School Readiness programme (e.g. Big Hopes-Big Futures) • Peri/post-natal support groups • Targeted mental health and wellbeing programmes • Counselling • Volunteer training and recruitment • Information, Advice, Guidance (IAG) and signposting • Food Bank Voucher distribution • Family activity days Our main funders are The Big Lottery Fund, BBC Children in Need, Virgin/Banardo’s PB-19yrs Contract, Essex Community Foundation, Clinical Commissioning Groups and local trusts. A new 5-Year Strategic Plan will be launched in March 2018 which will see HSE developing its funding streams to be more diverse; allowing the organisation to grow and build on excellent practice. Since April 2017, HSE has supported 368 families and 755 children, with over 200 trained volunteers offering 1,834 home visits, totalling 3,006 hours’ time across Essex. 95% of all frontline delivery continues to be entirely volunteer led. It is currently estimated that over the course of one year, the value of HSE volunteer time will be over £72,000 (ONS figures https://goo.gl/Uwz2cz). HSE measures impact across 14 individual areas of need (e.g. isolation, mental health, family conflict, etc.) with over 80% of families showing significant positive change. “My volunteer made a huge difference. Someone who’s not going to judge and always took the time to stop and listen”. We know that our model allows us to engage with those who would otherwise be considered ‘hard to reach’. Families frequently tell us the impact of a volunteer, giving their time freely, can be far more meaningful than a paid statutory professional. Isolation and mental health issues remain the top two concerns for most of the families we support, and this often means their ability to access mainstream services is limited. This provides HSE a unique opportunity to implement our proposed PICoD Project (Preventative IAG Co-Design) project; a three-year co-produced, family-led process that will develop a new model of information, advice and guidance (IAG). This will be aimed at those predominantly in the peri/post-natal period; a key period for those at risk of poor mental health and well-being. As an existing provider of peri/postnatal services in Harlow, and with a strong history of peer/ volunteer led practice, HSE are ideally positioned to lead on the project; building on our expertise and ability to engage families; ensuring that their voice is not only heard, but responded to in practical, real terms. HSE are confident that the project is deliverable as commitment has been tested with partners (e.g. Virgin/Banardo’s and University of Essex (UofE)) who say objectives are both realistic and achievable. By drawing on our existing network of partners, and engagement with families, HSE are keen to shape the future of family led practice. We believe this is achievable by harnessing the voices and opinions of service users as a tool; to shape and influence the way in which future information, advice and service delivery is commissioned. At HSE, our approach to project design, development and delivery is thorough and systematic. At concept stage, HSE appoints a Project Lead and a Project Delivery Team to draft delivery plans (in a standard format) and undertake initial research. This involves liaising with stakeholders (staff, service users, potential funders and partners, etc.); testing project feasibility; identifying resource needs; establishing project milestones/dependencies/budgets; and undertaking SWOT analysis. This forms the foundation for funding applications/development, as part of the new 2018 Funding Strategy. Upon funding success, our Development Team hands over to the Project Delivery Team, who refine proposals and manage the initiative on an ongoing basis, reporting back to Management, Trustees and Funders in a structured way. This gives assurance to stakeholders involved, that the way HSE delivers projects, is transparent and well managed.

recipientOrganization.description: We aim to enhance lives by providing bespoke support for 11-25 year olds to overcome day to day difficulties. This is achieved by boosting confidence by helping young people identify their strengths and develop strategies, through opportunities for them to feel more confident and empowered. Our Drop-in’s provide 1-1 sessions with a Support Worker allowing a young person to explore their difficulties and feelings, in a safe environment. Through these sessions we help them to improve their communication with peers, families and agencies so they are more resilient. By learning skills that will help them to problem solve their issues in the future more positively. By identifying their qualities, we progress onto a range of youth led group activities, this helps them to hone in on their often, hidden talents. Current projects include: Harwich Inspired Youth Action (HIYA)for 11-18 years-Young People making a difference to their community. Wildlife Project-for 11-25 years- Young People involved in activities that support local wildlife Volunteer Programme-for 18-25 years-an opportunity to develop their knowledge and practical skills. Each of the above provides a base for Young People to develop their ideas and gives them the opportunity to try new things.

grants.description: My research Masters will focus on mental health, developing into my dissertation, which will investigate young women and mental health in the media. In core modules, I will have the opportunity to create my own health-focused research questions. The interdisciplinary Masters incorporates modules from Health Sciences and Sociology. These include ‘Mixed methods in health research’ which focuses on philosophical and practical foundations, ‘Evaluating interventions, Services and Health and Social Care’ which will allow me to identify and demonstrate the benefit of interventions to individual users, organisations or whole populations.’ ‘Social epidemiology: theories and methods for understanding the social determinants of health’ involves exploring methods and measurements, causation and controversies, social class and deprivation, and statistical analysis. The goals of my research are to locate individuals with mental health conditions at the fore of inquiry and to generate ideas to pursue changes that improve mental health for individuals and society. I would aim to advance understanding in mental health, an area of critical need. The goal of the dissertation is to conduct research in how to improve mental health media and remove negative stereotypes, which are a barrier for people to access services and support.

recipientOrganization.name: Sandford Talking Shop
recipientOrganization.description: We're a volunteer-led organisation in Sandford-on-Thames, serving this village, neighbouring Littlemore & Rose Hill. Set up to offer a much needed social hub we run a community shop & café: an invaluable, welcoming social space for isolated and vulnerable residents and a convenient, well-stocked, affordable shop, open on 6 days a week. Every Saturday morning we add our market, now a core event in the weekly diary: a source of good affordable local produce, an incubator space for new micro businesses and a vital route to market for local producers. Volunteers also run diverse groups and activities for the benefit of the community from our space: bike mechanic team, Knit & Stitch group, weekly table tennis sessions, gardening team, monthly lunch club for the elderly, monthly ‘Pay what you can’ Food Surplus Café and Good Neighbour scheme. We deliver these activities through a structured, inclusive volunteering programme offering supportive, independent volunteering opportunities for everyone, including people who for many reasons might struggle in mainstream work. Supported by local mental health charities, Restore and Response, we welcome volunteers rebuilding structure after mental ill-health, we have young and old volunteers, from diverse social and ethnic backgrounds. We won OCVA's Best Community Project 2017.

grants.description: This grant would enable us to design and deliver training, outreach activities and community events to reach more people, particularly the more vulnerable, to benefit from the range of services, activities and community connectivity provided by Talking Shop. Sharing food will be a focal point in our participatory approach, modelling inclusion and cohesion in the events. Staff/volunteer training (delivery- TS volunteers with external consultant) including: Inclusion and unconscious bias; inclusive leadership; Resilience, wellbeing, mindfulness. Mental Health First Aid training for managers and shift leaders (delivery- Restore) with support to cascade learning. Evening workshops building on this learning: 4 facilitated by Restore, discussing issues arising from diversity of needs among volunteers; 4 facilitated by our team with external consultant, defining sustainable culture of inclusion, writing content for practical implementation of TS Mission/Values. Outreach visits to local groups by volunteers, taster events and community workshops in our space (eg. weekly drop-ins for young families, board games for older residents and those who live alone, peer to peer learning (cooking, gardening etc) ). A calendar of community activities proposed and promoted by local volunteers (suggestions - Arts Week, Big Lunch, Black History week, International Women’s Day, Mental Health Awareness Week), then becoming annual events.
grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity

grants.description: The main objectives of REACH are to determine the:1. Feasibility of delivering psychiatric consultation services via tele-psychiatry to patients with mental health problemsidentified in primary care. Vast number of patients in India access health care at the primary level however availability ofmental heath care is poor in these settings. This is largely due to lack of trained mental health manpower. Further thehealth personnel at primary level are poorly trained to identify and treat mental health issues. It will not be possible tobridge this mental health treatment gap in the near future hence this innovative use of tele-psychiatry viavideoconferencing is being considered. Though telepsychiatry has been used in some settings it remains to be seen if it can be integrated into the primary health system, which if found to be possible would have significant impact on mentalhealth care delivery in India. We aim to demonstrate that it is feasible to integrate such services into routine primary healthcare.2. Acceptability of tele-psychiatry services to various stakeholders including the delivery agents, patients, and their familymembers. One of the challenges would be engaging the end user and the peripheral health team in delivering care in asafe and acceptable manner. Besides feasibility and acceptability there are other concerns in delivering such a servicesuch as issues of privacy, confidentiality, record-keeping, ethical and legal implications as well as duty of care andhandling of emergencies. The study will delve into these issues through in-depth interviews with all stakeholders.3. Preliminary impact of psychiatric consultation services delivered via tele-psychiatry on various outcomes in patients with mental health problems identified in primary care. We will recruit patients identified with Depression, Alcohol use disorders and Severe Mental Illness; before-after assessments of symptom burden and disability levels will be done to determine the impact of the tele-psychiatric consultations. We hope to demonstrate that providing mental health care through telepsychiatry has a positive effect on the outcomes.

grants.description:
Shattered Minds: Our Traumatic Wars is a  public engagement project using a serris of shoet animated films which  examining the psychological effects of war from 1916 to the present day. The project is timed to coincide with the anniversary of the Battle of the Somme – a key event in the history of War Trauma.
Shattered Minds is aimed at helping multiple audiences to develop an increased understanding and awareness of War Trauma. Key to this strategy is the reduction of both the latency period between onset of symptoms and diagnosis of PTSD amongst Veterans (13 years) and the reduction of stigmas within the armed forces, veterans’ community and the general population that currently prevents many servicemen and women with mental health issues seeking help.
Shattered Minds involves a collection of partners across the UK including museums, galleries, newspapers (print and online), mental-health charities, and mental health service providers – each of whom will engage with the project in different ways, resulting in a comprehensive and multi-layered engagement strategy, bringing together different audiences including mental health service users, health professionals, the military and the general public, from young to old, across the nations and regions of the UK.

recipientOrganization.name: Zimbabwe National Association for Mental Health

grants.description: Zimbabwean culture has always valued drama and its subcomponents of music and dance as a crucial element to community socialization and fostering unity. Drawing from some of the experience of our collaborators and technical advisors, who have successfully engaged the public in creative ways, we hope to use this medium of community socialization that has never been exploited as a creative tool for public engagement addressing psychosis. Therefore, the Early Intervention in Psychosis (EIP) project seeks to introduce community arts and culture competition (Z factor) as a creative way of opening up conversations, sparking public debate, and tackling stigma attached to psychosis in rural Zimbabwe. The end goal being to increase understanding of community perceptions as well as increase community awareness about psychosis, collaborating to promote early detection and encourage seeking treatment as early as possible.  Current work by EIP in rural Zimbabwe has identified a deeply embedded traditional belief system which has led to the stigmatisation of psychosis. This psychosis themed drama competition will help to combat stigma by offering alternative explanations as well as learning more about the community belief system, with a hope to identify suggestions for further exploration in which the two care pathways may collaborate.

grants.title: Z Factor

grants.description:
The project aims to encourage research in the historic archive of the North Wales Hospital. The
objectives are to catalogue, list and package the archive, to promote it as an important academic
resource and to explain the Hospital’s history to the wider public. The hospital was the main institution in North Wales for the care of the mentally ill for almost 150 years, opening in October 1848 and closing in 1995.
The completion of the project will see:


  An itemised catalogue of the existing accessions re-catalogued to current standards.
  An itemised catalogue of later accessions of administration records.
  The later accession of patient case files will be listed and repackaged.
 The collection will be assessed for conservation needs and preventive preservation measures highlighted and put in place.
 The collection will be assessed for potential digitisation projects/digital resources.


Our target audiences are those involved in historical research, both from a higher education and a
leisure perspective. The project will make the North Wales Hospital collection accessible to the
wider community, providing an invaluable resource to academia whilst making the publicly available
material more accessible to the non-academic general user.

grants.title: Unlocking the Asylum: North Wales Hospital Archive 1848-1995

grants.description: The project I wish to undertake is to research the life of the late Audrey Amiss, via the eighty-four boxes and many paintings held at Wellcome. The boxes contain Audrey Amiss’s sketches, scrap-books, letters, diaries, photographs and other materials donated by the family. Audrey Amiss, an artist who worked as a civil service typist for most of her life, was diagnosed in her mid-twenties with paranoid schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. She entered her first psychiatric hospital at this point and, up till her death in 2013, just short of her 80th birthday, was a "revolving door" psychiatric patient/user, referring to herself in later years as a "mental health survivor". My chief goals are to use the research to ultimately write a screenplay for a feature film based on Audrey’s life and, in addition, I wish to use the research to write a book about Audrey and her artwork. Both the book and the screenplay and subsequent film will give valuable insight into the life of an artist and living with various mental health diagnoses.

grants.title: AUDREY AMISS COLLECTION

grants.description:
This project will bring a proven, flexible, popular software package into a new era of open, global, large-scale data collection. Many studies in behavioural sciences (psychology, neuroscience, linguistics and mental health) use computers to present stimuli and record responses in a precise manner. These studies are still typically conducted on small numbers of people in laboratory environments with dedicated hardware.

With improved web technologies, high-speed broadband, and smart devices everywhere, studies can now run on the web without sacrificing high temporal precision. This is a "game changer" in terms of the research that can be conducted. Data can be collected on larger, more varied, international populations. We can study people in environments they don’t find intimidating, and multiple times per day, without data collection becoming impractical.

We need better tools to create those studies. PsychoPy is a cross-platform open-source software package for creating experiments using OpenGL and Python. It is hugely popular mostly because relatively non-technical users can generate an enormous range of studies with high precision. This project will make it possible for those same studies to be conducted online, and on Android/iOS, by providing JavaScript/HTML/WebGL outputs and a secure server from which users can run their studies.

grants.description: Functional connectivity within and between large-scale brain networks is disrupted in a range of mental disorders. Current network-based explanations of mental disorders have led to ambiguous conclusions, with different clinical conditions being associated with disruption of the same functional networks. My recent work has shown that heteromodal regions of the cortex can be decomposed to reveal a 'local functional architecture' (LFA) of separable subregions with distinct activation timecourses.  Exploring this deeper LFA-level could disambiguate the neural basis of a range of mental illnesses. I will develop a novel analysis technique for the study of individual differences in brain activity at the LFA-level. My first goal will be to optimise a group-wise analysis technique I have developed (2,3) for use within individual subjects. I will apply the technique to large fMRI databases to explore to what extent LFA-level features such as subregion size and functional connectivity with ot her brain structures are conserved across the population. I will then use machine-learning techniques to test which LFA features relate to individual variability in a range of cognitive and personality inventories. Having identified candidate LFA features, I will test for group-wise differences in LFA properties in two psychiatric populations, schizophrenia and unipolar depression.

grants.description: In 2014, the Bethlem Royal Hospital Archives & Museum will move into the hospital's Art Deco administration block. Built in 1930, this building reflects a largely unexplored era of the ancient institution. New research and photography will reveal the history of the hospital at Monks Orchard, which has been overshadowed by interest in Victorian 'Bedlam'. Oral histories, collected from those who worked and lived in the building (at first used as staff accommodation) will supplement textual rese arch and photographic documentation of the architecture, bringing post-war psychiatry to life. By combining archive research with individual stories and new photographic documentation, this project will create a space in which academic historians and current and former staff and service users can work together and share skills and experience to create two temporary exhibitions and a permanent local history archive. The project will incorporate the perspectives of mental health staff and se rvice users at every stage. All members of the core project team have either worked in or used mental health services (or both). This background will enable sustainable opportunities for collaboration between mental health staff and service users and the academic history of psychiatry. Focus groups and events will increase public understanding of mental healthcare, aiding destigmatisation by encouraging audiences to consider their attitudes toward mental illness: in particular, the ongoing prese nce of inpatient treatment in the 'care in the community' era.

recipientOrganization.description: Runnymede and Spelthorne Citizens Advice Bureau (CAB) is a fully independent registered charity (registered in 2009). It is a member of the national Citizens Advice Association. The aims of Citizens Advice are to provide advice people need for problems they face and to improve policies and practices affecting people's lives. There are two main offices, in Addlestone and Sunbury Library, offering drop-ins five and three days per week. Unpaid volunteers give their time to help their fellow citizens by providing free, independent, confidential and impartial advice on rights and responsibilities. The CAB also operates an outreach service at the Abraham Cowley Unit, for users of mental health services. There are also outreach services in Stanwell and Englefield Green. Runnymede and Spelthorne CAB provide a Home Visiting service to people who are housebound, as well as the Runnymede Rentstart (RR) service. RR is based in Addlestone and provides assistance with finding privately rented accommodation, providing a deposit in the form of a guarantee bond, rent in advance and tenancy support.  Support is given to singles and couples with no children who have low or no income. Rentstart aims to help vulnerable local people who are homeless or faced with homelessness. Runnymede and Spelthorne CAB is overseen by a committee of 9 Trustees, the Rentstart project has two part-time employees. Local solicitors and other contacts provide additional support.
